('78', 111, 4, 5, 237754) 108. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('78', 111, 5, 6, 237785) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, April 4, 1940
('78', 111, 6, 7, 237817) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW,
('78', 111, 7, 8, 237839) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad writes a long letter from which I enclose herewith the relevant portion.
('78', 111, 8, 9, 237936) 1 C. F. Andrews was operated upon at Dr. Riordans Nursing Home on Sunday, March 31. 2 The letter dated March 30, 1940, inter alia, read : A friend from Delhi, who very often meets the Viceroy, has sent a letter to me.
('78', 111, 8, 10, 238154) He says that the impression left by your last interview on Linlithgow was that at first you wanted to lead him up to a certain point, and when he tried to reach it, then you left him altogether.
('78', 111, 8, 11, 238349) He further writes that if you had cleared the position from the very beginning that the Dominion Status of the Westminster variety would not be acceptable to you, the Viceroy would have comprehended the situation.
('78', 111, 8, 12, 238563) But it was not done.
('78', 111, 8, 13, 238584) You insisted on the reply of the question whether the Status conferred on India would be of the Westminster variety or not.
('78', 111, 8, 14, 238708) Linlithgow drew the conclusion that if he would get this point cleared, a way for further negotiation would be opened.
('78', 111, 8, 15, 238827) He drew the attention of the Home Government to this fact with all emphasis, and assured her that his position would be strengthened if he gets a chance of making such a statement.
('78', 111, 8, 16, 239008) He also insisted that so far as that declaration was concerned, it should not be mixed up with the communal problem.
('78', 111, 8, 17, 239125) The League may be opposed to it to any extent, but the political destiny of India could not be now changed.
('78', 111, 8, 18, 239233) But when the basis of negotiation was clarified, and he (the Viceroy) made an announcement with the surest hope of your approval, then all of a sudden you changed your attitude and declared quite unequivocally that India could not accept it.
('78', 111, 8, 19, 239475) This weakened the position of Linlithgow, and the Home Government considered him to be incapable of understanding and dealing with Indian situation.
('78', 111, 8, 20, 239624) In short, Linlithgow had a deep grievance against your attitude.
('78', 112, 0, 1, 239689) VOL. 78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 113
('78', 112, 1, 2, 239735) I shall be painfully surprised if you can confirm the report received by the Maulana Saheb.
('78', 112, 1, 3, 239827) Mine was a simple inquiry.
('78', 112, 1, 4, 239854) We had come so near each other that there was no mental reservation between us.
('78', 112, 1, 5, 239934) And if anything was left obscure there was no difficulty about going straight to the point and clearing obscurities.
('78', 112, 1, 6, 240051) That Dominion Status was not acceptable to the Congress had been cleared at the interview 1 which led to my inquiry.
('78', 112, 1, 7, 240168) The object was to know where each party exactly stood.
('78', 112, 1, 8, 240223) I should be very sorry indeed to discover that I left on your mind the impression that if Dominion Status of the Statute of Westminster variety was meant, the Congress would accept it.
('78', 112, 1, 9, 240408) I must refuse to give any credence to the suggestion that you had lost caste with the Cabinet because you had allowed yourself to be overreached by me as the report implies.
('78', 112, 1, 10, 240582) I have not known British statecraft to be so easily moved from its dispositions as suggested by Maulana Sahebs correspondent.
('78', 112, 1, 11, 240708) And I shall hope that you could never consider me guilty of wanting to overreach you.
('78', 112, 1, 12, 240794) Whilst I am writing to you, I want to have another thing also off my mind.
('78', 112, 1, 13, 240869) I have already told you that in my son Devdas you have a warm hearted champion.
('78', 112, 1, 14, 240949) He has been writing long letters to me trying to convince me that I did you a gross injustice in abruptly terminating our last conversation.
('78', 112, 1, 15, 241090) He discounts my assurance that the conversation ended because both you and I saw that the gulf between us was found to be too unbridgeable to be handled at that moment by prolonging conversations.
('78', 112, 1, 16, 241287) Indeed it was your expression that it would be more manly for us to end the conversations the very day we began them and make the confession to the public.
('78', 112, 1, 17, 241443) I at once accepted the accuracy of your characterization.
('78', 112, 1, 18, 241501) Devdas says, that was said out of courtesy if not British pride, and that you were eager to prolong the conversations.
('78', 112, 1, 19, 241620) He is thus most disconsolate and thinks that my interpretation of your attitude is wrong.
('78', 112, 1, 20, 241710) You alone can help me to settle this domestic dispute.
('78', 112, 1, 21, 241765) 2 M. K. G.
('78', 112, 2, 22, 241776) From a copy : C.W. 7843. Courtesy : G. D. Birla

('78', 114, 3, 13, 244111) DEAR SIR RADHAKRISHNAN, I could not reply per return.
('78', 114, 3, 14, 244165) Mass C. D. may or may not come.
('78', 114, 3, 15, 244197) There is room for two or more opinions.

('78', 114, 3, 21, 244621) My whole life has been cast in the first mould, to yield nothing on the fundamentals, no matter how weak one may feel.
('78', 114, 3, 22, 244740) Up to now I have had no cause for regret in having adopted that course.

('78', 115, 8, 20, 246261) KANCHAN, I have written more than one letter to you.
('78', 115, 8, 21, 246314) You are doing well.

('78', 117, 2, 13, 248979) I am buoyed up by my faith in its efficacy; the millions may not have caught that faith, and it may be that civil war will be the price we have to pay for our liberty.

('78', 120, 5, 7, 255748) Q. You have rightly said that no one who has not renounced untouchability in every shape and form can take part in satyagraha.

('78', 120, 8, 16, 256666) STATE PRAJA MANDALS
('78', 120, 9, 17, 256686) Q. What is the duty, in the event of civil disobedience, of members of Praja Mandals in the States and the rest of the people of the States ?
('78', 120, 10, 18, 256828) A. If civil disobedience is started by the Congress, it will be as against the British Government.
('78', 120, 10, 19, 256927) The people of the States cannot and ought not to offer any civil disobedience in the States.
('78', 120, 10, 20, 257020) Hence it follows that the Praja Mandals will remain unaffected by the Congress civil disobedience.
('78', 120, 10, 21, 257119) But individuals of the States can, if they wish, join the civil disobedience campaign in British India.
('78', 120, 10, 22, 257223) They can, therefore, send in their names to the nearest Congress Committee outside their State.

('78', 121, 1, 4, 257836) In such a case, I cannot declare civil disobedience; but it will be open to the Congress to repudiate me and declare civil disobedience independently of me.

('78', 124, 1, 8, 265011) Therefore, if I can help it, there will be no Congress ministry without a substantial communal settlement.
('78', 124, 1, 9, 265118) I am quite clear that real independence is impossible without a consistent non violent technique.
('78', 124, 1, 10, 265216) I am equally clear that there is hope of India gaining real independence if the Congress will refuse to compromise on it and will adhere to the means and for so doing dare to wander in the wilderness.
('78', 124, 1, 11, 265417) The Khaksar menace is no menace in itself.
('78', 124, 1, 12, 265460) As a symptom of a deeper disease it is a portent.
('78', 124, 1, 13, 265510) To bring into being rival organizations is a simple thing, but it is no remedy.
('78', 124, 1, 14, 265590) It merely multiplies the evil.
('78', 124, 1, 15, 265621) If I had my way, I would ask the people to meet the Khaksar violence with non violence.
('78', 124, 1, 16, 265709) But from the papers and the correspondence before me, I observe that the people seek outside protection against the danger, real or imaginary.
('78', 124, 1, 17, 265852) That means the consolidation of existing authority, supplemented perhaps by private defensive preparations.
('78', 124, 1, 18, 265960) I am interested in neither.
('78', 124, 1, 19, 265988) I have not discussed the terrible toll of deaths the Khaksars had to pay.
('78', 124, 1, 20, 266062) My sympathies are wholly with the bereaved families.
('78', 124, 1, 21, 266115) I say nothing about the shooting.
('78', 124, 1, 22, 266149) A special tribunal is inquiring into the whole affair.
('78', 124, 1, 23, 266204) If the tragedy leads to a searching of hearts, whatever the finding of the Committee, it will not have been enacted in vain.
('78', 124, 1, 24, 266329) SEVAGRAM, April 8, 1940 Harijan, 13 4 1940
('78', 124, 2, 25, 266372) 1Vide Our Failure, before 22 3 1938, and Speech at Kalukhan, 21 5 1938.
('78', 125, 0, 1, 266444) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 125, 1, 2, 266486) 122. TWO QUESTIONS FROM AMERICA
('78', 125, 2, 3, 266518) A friend writing from America propounds the following two questions 1 :
('78', 125, 3, 4, 266590) 1. Granted that satyagraha is capable of winning Indias independence, what are the chances of its being accepted as a principle of State policy in a free India ?
('78', 125, 3, 5, 266752) Is satyagraha likely to be accepted only in an up hill battle, when the phenomenon of martyrdom is fully effective, or is it also to be the instrument of a sovereign authority which has neither the need nor the scope of behaving on the principle of martyrdom ?
('78', 125, 4, 6, 267013) 2. Suppose a free India adopts satyagraha as an instrument of State policy, how would she defend herself against probable aggression by another sovereign State ?
('78', 125, 4, 7, 267175) What would be the satyagrahic action patterns to meet the invading army at the frontier ?
('78', 125, 4, 8, 267265) The questions are admittedly theoretical.
('78', 125, 4, 9, 267307) They are also premature for the reason that I have not mastered the whole technique of non violence.
('78', 125, 4, 10, 267408) The experiment is still in the making.
('78', 125, 4, 11, 267447) It is not even in its advanced stage.
('78', 125, 4, 12, 267485) The nature of the experiment requires one to be satisfied with one step at a time.
('78', 125, 4, 13, 267568) The distant scene is not for him to see.
('78', 125, 4, 14, 267609) Therefore my answers can only be speculative.
('78', 125, 4, 15, 267655) In truth, as I have said before, now we are not having unadulterated non violence even in our struggle to win independence.
('78', 125, 4, 16, 267779) As to the first question, I fear that the chances of non violence being accepted as a principle of State policy are very slight, so far as I can see at present.
('78', 125, 4, 17, 267940) If India does not accept non violence as her policy after winning independence, the second question becomes superfluous.
('78', 125, 4, 18, 268061) But I may state my own individual view of the potency of non violence.
('78', 125, 4, 19, 268132) I believe that a State can be administered on a non violent basis if the vast majority of the people are non violent.
('78', 125, 4, 20, 268250) So far as I know, India is the only country which has a possibility of being such a State.
('78', 125, 4, 21, 268341) I am conducting my experiment in that faith.
('78', 125, 4, 22, 268386) Supposing, therefore, that India attained independence through pure non violence, India could retain it too by the same means.
('78', 125, 4, 23, 268513) A non violent man or society does not anticipate or provide for attacks from without.
('78', 125, 4, 24, 268599) On the contrary such a person or society firmly believes that
('78', 125, 5, 25, 268661) 1 Of which only extracts are reproduced here
('78', 126, 0, 1, 268706) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 127
('78', 126, 1, 2, 268751) nobody is going to disturb them.
('78', 126, 1, 3, 268784) If the worst happens, there are two ways open to non violence.
('78', 126, 1, 4, 268847) To yield possession but non cooperate with the aggressor.
('78', 126, 1, 5, 268905) Thus, supposing that a modern edition of Nero descended upon India, the representatives of the State will let him in but tell him that he will get no assistance from the people.
('78', 126, 1, 6, 269083) They will prefer death to submission.
('78', 126, 1, 7, 269121) The second way would be non violent resistance by the people who have been trained in the non violent way.
('78', 126, 1, 8, 269228) They would offer themselves unarmed as fodder for the aggressors cannons.
('78', 126, 1, 9, 269302) The underlying belief in either case is that even a Nero is not devoid of a heart.
('78', 126, 1, 10, 269385) The unexpected spectacle of endless rows upon rows of men and women simply dying rather than surrender to the will of an aggressor must ultimately melt him and his soldiery.
('78', 126, 1, 11, 269559) Practically speaking, there will be probably no greater loss in men than if forcible resistance was offered; there will be no expenditure in armaments and fortifications.
('78', 126, 1, 12, 269730) The non violent training received by the people will add inconceivably to their moral height.
('78', 126, 1, 13, 269824) Such men and women will have shown personal bravery of a type far superior to that shown in armed warfare.
('78', 126, 1, 14, 269931) In each case the bravery consists in dying, not in killing.
('78', 126, 1, 15, 269991) Lastly, there is no such thing as defeat in non violent resistance.
('78', 126, 1, 16, 270059) That such a thing has not happened before is no answer to my speculation.
('78', 126, 1, 17, 270133) I have drawn no impossible picture.
('78', 126, 1, 18, 270169) History is replete with instances of individual non violence of the type I have mentioned.
('78', 126, 1, 19, 270260) There is no warrant for saying or thinking that a group of men and women cannot by sufficient training act non violently as a group or nation.
('78', 126, 1, 20, 270403) Indeed, the sum total of the experience of mankind is that men somehow or other live on.
('78', 126, 1, 21, 270492) From which fact I infer that it is the law of love that rules mankind.
('78', 126, 1, 22, 270563) Had violence, i.e., hate, ruled us, we should have become extinct long ago.
('78', 126, 1, 23, 270639) And yet the tragedy of it is that the so called civilized men and nations conduct themselves as if the basis of society was violence.
('78', 126, 1, 24, 270773) It gives me ineffable joy to make experiments proving that love is the supreme and only law of life.
('78', 126, 1, 25, 270874) Much evidence to the contrary cannot shake my faith.
('78', 126, 1, 26, 270927) Even the mixed non violence of India has supported it.
('78', 126, 1, 27, 270982) But if it is not enough to convince an unbeliever, it is enough to incline a friendly critic to view it with favour.
('78', 126, 1, 28, 271099) SEVAGRAM, April 8, 1940
('78', 126, 2, 29, 271123) Harijan, 13 4 1940
('78', 127, 0, 1, 271142) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('78', 127, 2, 3, 271215) April 8, 1940
('78', 127, 3, 4, 271229) MY DEAR KU[MARAPPA], Dr. Mehta gave a bad report of your gross misbehaviour.
('78', 127, 3, 5, 271306) You must bring down your b.p.
('78', 127, 3, 6, 271336) It is suggested that you should come and stay here for a few days and be under observation.
('78', 127, 3, 7, 271428) Then during the hot season you should go up somewhere and rest.
('78', 127, 3, 8, 271492) The brain requires more rest than the body.
('78', 127, 3, 9, 271536) You can come today, if you will.

('78', 127, 6, 11, 271599) 124. NOTES
('78', 127, 7, 12, 271610) ANDREWS LEGACY
('78', 127, 8, 13, 271625) Nobody probably knew Charlie Andrews as well as I did.
('78', 127, 8, 14, 271680) Gurudev was gurumasterto him.
('78', 127, 8, 15, 271710) When we met in South Africa, we simply met as brothers and remained as such to the end.
('78', 127, 8, 16, 271798) There was no distance between us.
('78', 127, 8, 17, 271832) It was not a friendship between an Englishman and an Indian.
('78', 127, 8, 18, 271893) It was an unbreakable bond between two seekers and servants.
('78', 127, 8, 19, 271954) But I am not giving my reminiscences of Andrews, sacred as they are.
('78', 127, 8, 20, 272023) I want Englishmen and Indians, whilst the memory of the death of this servant of England and India is still fresh, to give a thought to the legacy he has left for us both.
('78', 127, 8, 21, 272195) There is no doubt about his love for England being equal to that of the tallest of Englishmen, nor can there be any doubt of his love for India being equal to that of the tallest of Indians.
('78', 127, 8, 22, 272386) He said on his bed from which he was never to rise, Mohan, swaraj is coming. Both Englishmen and Indians can make it come, if they will.
('78', 127, 8, 23, 272523) Andrews was no stranger to the present rulers and most Englishmen whose opinion carries weight.
('78', 127, 8, 24, 272619) He was known to every politically minded Indian.
('78', 127, 8, 25, 272668) At the present moment I do not wish to think of English misdeeds.
('78', 127, 8, 26, 272734) They will be forgotten, but not one of the heroic deeds of Andrews will be forgotten so long as England and India live.
('78', 127, 8, 27, 272854) If we really love Andrews memory, we may not have hate in us for Englishmen, of whom Andrews was among the best and the noblest.
('78', 127, 8, 28, 272983) It is possible, quite possible, for the best
('78', 128, 0, 1, 273028) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 129
('78', 128, 1, 2, 273073) Englishmen and the best Indians to meet together and never to separate till they have evolved a formula acceptable to both.
('78', 128, 1, 3, 273197) The legacy left by Andrews is worth the effort.
('78', 128, 1, 4, 273245) That is the thought that rules me whilst I contemplate the benign face of Andrews and what innumerable deeds of love he performed so that India may take her independent place among the nations of the earth.
('78', 128, 1, 5, 273452) HOW NOT TO DO IT
('78', 128, 2, 6, 273469) Ranga 1 is a co worker whom I have had the pleasure of knowing for a long time.
('78', 128, 2, 7, 273549) He is brave and good natured, but he has the knack of often saying things he ought not to and doing wrong things at the wrong time.
('78', 128, 2, 8, 273681) He sent me a telegram when he had decided to break the order of internment served upon him.
('78', 128, 2, 9, 273773) He knew that he was under discipline.
('78', 128, 2, 10, 273811) If he had left me the time, I should have asked him to obey the order to confine himself to his place, Nidubrole.
('78', 128, 2, 11, 273925) By compliance he would have shown a fine spirit of discipline and today he would be doing constructive work in his place and earning the privilege of joining the civil disobedience brigade.
('78', 128, 2, 12, 274115) As it is, in my opinion, he has harmed the cause and done no good to himself or anybody.
('78', 128, 2, 13, 274204) He has harmed the cause by setting a bad example to those who look up to him for guidance.
('78', 128, 2, 14, 274295) If I could persuade him, I would certainly advise him to inform the authorities that he had committed a breach of internal discipline for which he was sorry and that, if he was discharged, he would gladly proceed to Nidubrole and remain there till the order of internment was withdrawn.
('78', 128, 2, 15, 274582) I make bold to say that, if he followed my advice, he would help me and help the countrys cause.
('78', 128, 2, 16, 274679) SEVAGRAM, April 9, 1940
('78', 128, 3, 17, 274703) Harijan, 13 4 1940
('78', 128, 4, 18, 274722) 125. CHARKHA SWARAJ AHIMSA
('78', 128, 5, 19, 274749) A correspondent says now that civil disobedience is in the air, I must once more, even at the risk of repeating myself, summarize in a single article my argument showing that there is a vital connection between the charkha, swaraj and ahimsa.
('78', 128, 5, 20, 274992) I gladly make the attempt.
('78', 128, 5, 21, 275019) The spinning wheel represents to me the hope of the masses.
('78', 128, 5, 22, 275079) The masses lost their freedom, such as it was, with the loss of the
('78', 128, 6, 23, 275147) 1 N. G. Ranga
('78', 129, 0, 1, 275161) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 129, 1, 2, 275203) charkha.
('78', 129, 1, 3, 275212) The charkha supplemented the agriculture of the villagers and gave it dignity.
('78', 129, 1, 4, 275291) It was the friend and solace of the widow.
('78', 129, 1, 5, 275334) It kept the villagers from idleness.
('78', 129, 1, 6, 275371) For the charkha included all the anterior and posterior industriesginning, carding, warping, sizing, dyeing and weaving.
('78', 129, 1, 7, 275492) These in their turn kept the village carpenter and the blacksmith busy.
('78', 129, 1, 8, 275564) The charkha enabled the seven hundred thousand villages to become self contained.
('78', 129, 1, 9, 275646) With the exit of the charkha went the other village industries, such as the oil press.
('78', 129, 1, 10, 275733) Nothing took the place of these industries.
('78', 129, 1, 11, 275777) Therefore the villages were drained of their varied occupations and their creative talent and what little wealth these brought them.
('78', 129, 1, 12, 275910) The analogy of the other countries in which too village handicrafts were destroyed will not serve us because, whereas the villagers there had some compensating advantages, Indias villagers had practically none.
('78', 129, 1, 13, 276121) The industrialized countries of the West were exploiting other nations.
('78', 129, 1, 14, 276193) India is herself an exploited country.
('78', 129, 1, 15, 276232) Hence, if the villagers are to come into their own, the most natural thing that suggests itself is the revival of the charkha and all it means.
('78', 129, 1, 16, 276376) This revival cannot take place without an army of selfless Indians of intelligence and patriotism working with a single mind in the villages to spread the message of the charkha and bring a ray of hope and light into their lustreless eyes.
('78', 129, 1, 17, 276616) This is a mighty effort at co operation and adult education of the correct type.
('78', 129, 1, 18, 276697) It brings about a silent and sure revolution like the silent but sure and life giving revolution of the charkha.
('78', 129, 1, 19, 276810) Twenty years experience of charkha work has convinced me of the correctness of the argument here advanced by me.
('78', 129, 1, 20, 276923) The charkha has served the poor Muslims and Hindus in almost an equal measure.
('78', 129, 1, 21, 277002) Nearly five crores of rupees have been put into the pockets of these lakhs of village artisans without fuss and tomtomming.
('78', 129, 1, 22, 277126) Hence I say without hesitation that the charkha must lead us to swaraj in terms of the masses belonging to all faiths.
('78', 129, 1, 23, 277245) The charkha restores the villages to their rightful place and abolishes distinctions between high and low.
('78', 129, 1, 24, 277352) But the charkha cannot bring swaraj, in fact it will not move, unless the nation has faith in non violence.
('78', 129, 1, 25, 277460) It is not exciting enough.
('78', 129, 1, 26, 277487) Patriots yearning for freedom are apt to look down upon the charkha.
('78', 129, 1, 27, 277556) They will look in vain to find it in history books.
('78', 129, 1, 28, 277608) Lovers of liberty are
('78', 130, 0, 1, 277630) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 131
('78', 130, 1, 2, 277675) fired with the zeal to fight and banish the foreign ruler.
('78', 130, 1, 3, 277734) They impute all the vices to him and see none in themselves.
('78', 130, 1, 4, 277795) They cite instances of countries having gained their freedom through seas of blood.
('78', 130, 1, 5, 277879) The charkha devoid of violence seems an utterly tame affair.
('78', 130, 1, 6, 277940) In 1919 the lovers of the liberty of India were introduced to non violence as the only and sure means to swaraj and to the charkha as a symbol of non violence.
('78', 130, 1, 7, 278100) The charkha found its proud place on the national flag in 1921. But non violence had not gone deep into the heart of India, and so the charkha never came into its own.
('78', 130, 1, 8, 278268) It will never come into its own unless the vast body of Congressmen develop a living faith in non violence.
('78', 130, 1, 9, 278376) When they do so they will, without needing any argument, discover for themselves that there is no other symbol of non violence than the charkha, and that without its universalization there will be no visible expression of non violence.
('78', 130, 1, 10, 278612) It is common ground that without non violence there can be no non violent disobedience.
('78', 130, 1, 11, 278700) My argument may be false, my data may be faulty.
('78', 130, 1, 12, 278749) But, holding the views I do, let me proclaim that without fulfilment of the conditions prescribed by me I simply cannot declare civil disobedience.
('78', 130, 1, 13, 278897) SEVAGRAM, April 9, 1940
('78', 130, 2, 14, 278921) Harijan, 13 4 1940
('78', 130, 3, 15, 278940) 126. MY POSITION
('78', 130, 4, 16, 278957) Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan has, in his criticism 1 of my reply 2
('78', 130, 5, 17, 279022) to Quaid e Azam, put some questions which I gladly answer.
('78', 130, 5, 18, 279081) I must adhere to my statement that I have never spoken to anybody on the communal questions as a Hindu.
('78', 130, 5, 19, 279185) I have no authority.
('78', 130, 5, 20, 279206) Whenever I have spoken to anybody I have spoken as a Congressman, but often only as an individual.
('78', 130, 5, 21, 279305) No Congressman, not even the President, can always speak as a representative.
('78', 130, 5, 22, 279383) Big things have always been transacted on this planet by persons belonging to different organizations coming together and talking informally in their non representative capacity.
('78', 130, 5, 23, 279562) I fear that even the answer I am about to give must be taken as representing nobody but myself.
('78', 130, 5, 24, 279658) In the present instance I have reason to say that probably I do not represent any single member of the
('78', 130, 6, 25, 279761) 1 For extracts from Liaquat Ali Khans statement, vide Appendix Extracts from Liaquat Ali Khans Statement, 4 4 1940. 2 Vide My Answer to Quaid E Azam, 30 3 1940.
('78', 131, 0, 1, 279922) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 131, 1, 2, 279964) Working Committee.
('78', 131, 1, 3, 279983) I am answering as a peacemaker, as a friend (and may I say brother) of the Mussalmans.
('78', 131, 1, 4, 280070) As a man of non violence I cannot forcibly resist the proposed partition if the Muslims of India really insist upon it.
('78', 131, 1, 5, 280190) But I can never be a willing party to the vivisection.
('78', 131, 1, 6, 280245) I would employ every non violent means to prevent it.
('78', 131, 1, 7, 280299) For it means the undoing of centuries of work done by numberless Hindus and Muslims to live together as one nation.
('78', 131, 1, 8, 280415) Partition means a patent untruth.
('78', 131, 1, 9, 280449) My whole soul rebels against the idea that Hinduism and Islam represent two antagonistic cultures and doctrines.
('78', 131, 1, 10, 280562) To assent to such a doctrine is for me denial of God.
('78', 131, 1, 11, 280616) For I believe with my whole soul that the God of the Koran is also the God of the Gita, and that we are all, no matter by what name designated, children of the same God.
('78', 131, 1, 12, 280786) I must rebel against the idea that millions of Indians who were Hindus the other day changed their nationality on adopting Islam as their religion.
('78', 131, 1, 13, 280934) But that is my belief.
('78', 131, 1, 14, 280957) I cannot thrust it down the throats of the Muslims who think that they are a different nation.
('78', 131, 1, 15, 281052) I refuse, however, to believe that the eight crores of Muslims will say that they have nothing in common with their Hindu and other brethren.
('78', 131, 1, 16, 281194) Their mind can only be known by a referendum duly made to them on that clear issue.
('78', 131, 1, 17, 281278) The contemplated Constituent Assembly can easily decide the question.
('78', 131, 1, 18, 281348) Naturally on an issue such as this there can be no arbitration.
('78', 131, 1, 19, 281412) It is purely and simply a matter of self determination.
('78', 131, 1, 20, 281468) I know of no other conclusive method of ascertaining the mind of the eight crores of Muslims.
('78', 131, 1, 21, 281562) But the contemplated Constituent Assembly will have the framing of a constitution as its main function.
('78', 131, 1, 22, 281666) It cannot do this until the communal question is settled.
('78', 131, 1, 23, 281724) I still believe that there can be no swaraj by non violent means without communal unity.
('78', 131, 1, 24, 281813) And eight crores of Muslims can certainly bar the way to peaceful freedom.
('78', 131, 1, 25, 281888) If then I still talk of civil disobedience, it is because I believe that the Muslim masses want freedom as much as the rest of the population of this country.
('78', 131, 1, 26, 282047) And assuming that they do not, civil disobedience will be a powerful means of educating public opinion whether Muslim, Hindu or any other.
('78', 131, 1, 27, 282186) It will also be an education of world opinion.
('78', 131, 1, 28, 282233) But I will not embark upon it unless I am, as far as is humanly possible, sure that non violence will be observed both in spirit and in the letter.
('78', 132, 0, 1, 282381) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 133
('78', 132, 1, 2, 282426) I hope the Nawabzada has no difficulty in believing that whatever is gained by civil disobedience will be gained for all.
('78', 132, 1, 3, 282548) When India gets the power to frame her own constitution, the Muslims will surely have a decisive voice in shaping their own future.
('78', 132, 1, 4, 282680) It will not be, cannot be, decided by the vote of the majority.
('78', 132, 1, 5, 282744) Lastly, I suggest to the Nawabzada that he wrote in haste the lines about the President of the Congress.
('78', 132, 1, 6, 282849) For they are contrary to the history of our own times.
('78', 132, 1, 7, 282904) And he was equally in haste in suggesting that the sole objective of the Congress under Mr. Gandhis fostering care has been the revival of Hinduism and the imposition of Hindu culture on all and sundry. My own objective is not the issue in the terrible indictment.
('78', 132, 1, 8, 283169) The objective of the Congress is wholly political.
('78', 132, 1, 9, 283220) Nothing is to be gained by making statements that are incapable of proof.
('78', 132, 1, 10, 283294) So far as my own objective is concerned my life is an open book.
('78', 132, 1, 11, 283359) I claim to represent all the cultures, for my religion, whatever it may be called, demands the fulfilment of all cultures.
('78', 132, 1, 12, 283482) I am at home wherever I go, for I regard all religions with the same respect as my own.
('78', 132, 1, 13, 283570) SEVAGRAM, April 9, 1940 Harijan, 13 4 1940

('78', 133, 6, 12, 284700) 129. LETTER TO PRITHVI SINGH SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, April 10, 1940
('78', 133, 7, 13, 284762) PRITHVI SINGH, I have your letter.
('78', 133, 7, 14, 284797) Must you write in English ?
('78', 133, 7, 15, 284825) I merely passed on the telegram I had received from Guntur.
('78', 133, 7, 16, 284885) I did not suggest that you should go.
('78', 133, 7, 17, 284923) But that is over now.

('78', 133, 7, 20, 285042) Need I give one to Mahadev ?
('78', 133, 7, 21, 285071) I do not intend to write anything.

('78', 141, 6, 9, 293392) 145. JAYAPRAKASHS PICTURE
('78', 141, 7, 10, 293418) The following draft resolution was sent to me by Shri Jayaprakash Narayan.
('78', 141, 7, 11, 293493) He asked me, if I accepted his picture, to put it before the Working Committee at Ramgarh.
('78', 141, 8, 12, 293584) The Congress and the country are on the eve of a great national upheaval.
('78', 141, 8, 13, 293658) The final battle for freedom is soon to be fought.
('78', 141, 8, 14, 293709) This will happen when the whole world is being shaken by mighty forces of change.
('78', 141, 8, 15, 293791) Out of the catastrophe of the European War, thoughtful minds everywhere are anxious to create a new worlda world based on the co operative goodwill of nations and men.
('78', 141, 8, 16, 293959) At such a time the Congress considers it necessary to state definitely the ideals of freedom for which it stands and for which it is soon to invite the Indian people to undergo the uttermost sufferings.
('78', 141, 9, 17, 294162) The free Indian nation shall work for peace between nations and total rejection
('78', 141, 10, 18, 294242) of armaments and for the method of peaceful settlement of national disputes through
('78', 141, 11, 19, 294326) some international authority freely established.
('78', 141, 11, 20, 294375) It will endeavour particularly to live
('78', 141, 12, 21, 294414) on the friendliest terms with its neighbours, whether they be great powers or small
('78', 141, 13, 22, 294498) nations, and shall covet no foreign territory.
('78', 141, 14, 23, 294545) The law of the land will be based on the will of the people freely expressed by them.
('78', 141, 14, 24, 294631) The ultimate basis of maintenance of order shall be the sanction and concurrence of the people.
('78', 141, 15, 25, 294727) The free Indian State shall guarantee full individual and civil liberty and cultural and religious freedom, provided that there shall be
('78', 141, 16, 26, 294864) no freedom to overthrow by violence the constitution framed by the Indian people through a Constituent Assembly.
('78', 142, 0, 1, 294977) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 143
('78', 142, 1, 2, 295022) The State shall not discriminate in any manner between citizens of the nation.
('78', 142, 1, 3, 295101) Every citizen shall be guaranteed equal rights.
('78', 142, 1, 4, 295149) All distinctions of birth and privilege shall be abolished.
('78', 142, 1, 5, 295209) There shall be no titles emanating either from inherited social status or the State.
('78', 142, 2, 6, 295294) The political and economic organization of the State shall be based on principles of social justice and economic freedom.
('78', 142, 2, 7, 295416) While this organization shall conduce to the satisfaction of the national requirements of every member of society, material satisfaction shall not be its sole objective.
('78', 142, 2, 8, 295586) It shall aim at healthy living and the moral and intellectual development of the individual.
('78', 142, 2, 9, 295679) To this end to secure social justice, the State shall endeavour to promote small scale production carried on by individual or co operative effort for the equal benefit of all concerned.
('78', 142, 2, 10, 295865) All large scale collective production shall be eventually brought under collective ownership and control, and in this behalf the State shall begin by nationalizing heavy transport, shipping, mining and the heavy industries.
('78', 142, 2, 11, 296089) The textile industry shall be progressively decentralized.
('78', 142, 3, 12, 296148) The life of the villages shall be reorganized and the villages shall be made self governing units, self sufficient in as large a measure as possible.
('78', 142, 3, 13, 296298) The land laws of the country shall be drastically reformed on the principle that land shall belong to the actual cultivator alone, and that no cultivator shall have more land than is necessary to support his family on a fair standard of living.
('78', 142, 3, 14, 296543) This will end the various systems of landlordism on the one hand and farm bondage on the other.
('78', 142, 4, 15, 296639) The State shall protect the interests of the classes, but when these impinge upon the interests of those who have been poor and downtrodden, it shall defend the latter and thus restore the balance of social justice.
('78', 142, 5, 16, 296855) In all State owned and State managed enterprises, the workers shall be represented in the management through their elected representatives and shall have an equal share in it with the representatives of the Government.
('78', 142, 6, 17, 297074) In the Indian States, there shall be complete democratic government established, and in accordance with the principles of abolition of social distinction and equality between citizens, there shall not be any titular heads of the States in the persons of Rajas and Nawabs.
('78', 142, 7, 18, 297346) This is the order which the Congress envisages and which it shall work to establish.
('78', 142, 7, 19, 297431) The Congress firmly believes that this order shall bring happiness, prosperity and freedom to the people of all races and religions in India who together shall build on these foundations a great and glorious nation.
('78', 142, 7, 20, 297647) I liked it and read his letter and the draft to the Working Committee 1. The Committee, however, thought that the idea of having
('78', 142, 8, 21, 297776) 1 On March 15; vide Discussion at Working Committee, 15 3 1940.
('78', 143, 0, 1, 297840) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 143, 1, 2, 297882) only one resolution for the Ramgarh Congress should be strictly adhered to, and that the original, as framed at Patna 1, should not be tampered with.
('78', 143, 1, 3, 298032) The reasoning of the Committee was unexceptionable, and the draft resolution was dropped without any discussion on merits.
('78', 143, 1, 4, 298155) I informed Shri Jayaprakash of the result of my effort.
('78', 143, 1, 5, 298211) He wrote back suggesting that he would be satisfied if I could do the next best thing, namely, publish it with full concurrence or such as I could give it.
('78', 143, 2, 6, 298367) I have no difficulty in complying with Shri Jayaprakashs wishes.
('78', 143, 2, 7, 298432) As an ideal to be reduced to practice as soon as possible after India comes into her own, I endorse in general all except one of the propositions enunciated by Shri Jayaprakash.
('78', 143, 2, 8, 298610) I have claimed that I was a socialist long before those I know in India had avowed their creed.
('78', 143, 2, 9, 298706) But my socialism was natural to me and not adopted from any books.
('78', 143, 2, 10, 298773) It came out of my unshakable belief in non violence.
('78', 143, 2, 11, 298826) No man could be actively non violent and not rise against social injustice no matter where it occurred.
('78', 143, 2, 12, 298930) Unfortunately Western socialists have, so far as I know, believed in the necessity of violence for enforcing socialistic doctrines.
('78', 143, 2, 13, 299062) I have always held that social justice, even unto the least and the lowliest, is impossible of attainment by force.
('78', 143, 2, 14, 299178) I have further believed that it is possible by proper training of the lowliest by non violent means to secure redress of the wrongs suffered by them.
('78', 143, 2, 15, 299328) That means is non violent non co operation.
('78', 143, 2, 16, 299372) At times non co operation becomes as much a duty as co operation.
('78', 143, 2, 17, 299438) No one is bound to co operate in ones own undoing or slavery.
('78', 143, 2, 18, 299500) Freedom received through the effort of others, however benevolent, cannot be retained when such effort is withdrawn.
('78', 143, 2, 19, 299617) In other words, such freedom is not real freedom.
('78', 143, 2, 20, 299667) But the lowliest can feel its glow as soon as they learn the art of attaining it through non violent non co operation.
('78', 143, 2, 21, 299786) It therefore gladdens me to find Shri Jayaprakash accepting, as I read his draft, non violence for the purpose of establishing the order envisaged by him.
('78', 143, 2, 22, 299941) I am quite sure that non violent non co operation can secure what violence never can, and this by ultimate conversion of the wrong doers.
('78', 143, 2, 23, 300079) We in India have never given non violence the trial it has deserved.
('78', 143, 2, 24, 300148) The marvel is that we have attained so much even with our mixed non violence.
('78', 143, 3, 25, 300226) 1 On March 1; vide Appendix A Resolution, 1 3 1940. 2 Vide Letter to Jayaprakash Narayan, 31 3 1940.
('78', 144, 0, 1, 300327) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 145
('78', 144, 1, 2, 300372) Shri Jayaprakashs propositions about land may appear frightful.
('78', 144, 1, 3, 300436) In reality they are not.
('78', 144, 1, 4, 300461) No man should have more land than he needs for dignified sustenance.
('78', 144, 1, 5, 300530) Who can dispute the fact that the grinding poverty of the masses is due to their having no land that they can call their own ?
('78', 144, 1, 6, 300657) But it must be realized that the reform cannot be rushed.
('78', 144, 1, 7, 300715) If it is to be brought about by non violent means, it can only be done by education both of the haves and the have nots.
('78', 144, 1, 8, 300836) The former should be assured that there never will be force used against them.
('78', 144, 1, 9, 300915) The have nots must be educated to know that no one can really compel them to do anything against their will, and that they can secure their freedom by learning the art of non violence, i.e., self suffering.
('78', 144, 1, 10, 301122) If the end in view is to be achieved, the education I have adumbrated has to be commenced now.
('78', 144, 1, 11, 301217) An atmosphere of mutual respect and trust has to be established as the preliminary step.
('78', 144, 1, 12, 301306) There can then be no violent conflict between the classes and the masses.
('78', 144, 1, 13, 301380) Whilst, therefore, I have no difficulty in generally endorsing Shri Jayaprakashs proposition in terms of non violence, I cannot endorse his proposition about the Princes.
('78', 144, 1, 14, 301551) In law they are independent.
('78', 144, 1, 15, 301580) It is true that their independence is not worth much, for it is guaranteed by a stronger party.
('78', 144, 1, 16, 301676) But as against us they are able to assert their independence.
('78', 144, 1, 17, 301738) If we come into our own through non violent means, as is implied in Shri Jayaprakashs draft proposals, I do not imagine a settlement in which the Princes will have effaced themselves.
('78', 144, 1, 18, 301922) Whatever settlement is arrived at the nation will have to carry out in full.
('78', 144, 1, 19, 301999) I can therefore only conceive a settlement in which the big States will retain their status.
('78', 144, 1, 20, 302092) In one way this will be far superior to what it is today; but in another it will be limited so as to give the people of the States the same right of self government within their States as the people of the other parts of India will enjoy.
('78', 144, 1, 21, 302331) They will have freedom of speech, a free Press and pure justice guaranteed to them.
('78', 144, 1, 22, 302415) Perhaps Shri Jayaprakash has no faith in the Princes automatically surrendering their autocracy.
('78', 144, 1, 23, 302512) I have.
('78', 144, 1, 24, 302520) First because they are just as good human beings as we are, and secondly because of my belief in the potency of genuine non violence.
('78', 144, 1, 25, 302654) Let me conclude, therefore, by saying that the Princes and all others will be true and amenable when we have become true to ourselves, to our faith, if we have it, and to the nation.
('78', 144, 1, 26, 302837) At present we are half hearted.
('78', 144, 1, 27, 302869) The way to freedom will never be found through half heartedness.
('78', 144, 1, 28, 302934) Non violence begins and ends by turning the searchlight inward.
('78', 144, 1, 29, 302998) SEVAGRAM, April 14, 1940 Harijan, 20 4 1930

('78', 146, 8, 14, 305292) 149. QUESTION BOX
('78', 146, 9, 15, 305310) DANGER OF DELAY
('78', 146, 10, 16, 305326) Q. You say you will not launch civil disobedience till Congressmen are fully trained in non violence and disciplined.
('78', 146, 10, 17, 305444) That is right.
('78', 146, 10, 18, 305459) But in the mean time the country is being bled white.
('78', 146, 10, 19, 305513) Increased railway fares, duty on sugar, the reduction of sugarcane prices are only a few instances in point.
('78', 146, 10, 20, 305622) Is it right to delay the struggle till our best workers are picked off one by one, and thus lose the fight without striking a blow ?
('78', 146, 11, 21, 305755) A. I can cite far more telling instances than you have given for justifying civil disobedience.
('78', 146, 11, 22, 305851) But civil disobedience is not being delayed for want of justification.
('78', 146, 11, 23, 305922) It is being delayed for want of preparation.
('78', 146, 11, 24, 305967) I should be a stupid General if I began the fight in spite of my knowledge that my resources are poor.
('78', 146, 11, 25, 306070) If the leaders are picked off by the Government without just cause, it would mean an invitation to the Congress to fight.
('78', 146, 11, 26, 306192) I would not answer the invitation if I were not ready.
('78', 146, 11, 27, 306247) The leaders being picked off can do the country no harm.
('78', 146, 11, 28, 306304) For we know that disciplined jail going is itself a part of the struggle.
('78', 146, 11, 29, 306378) Moreover, the imprisonment of leaders will test our strength as an organization.
('78', 146, 11, 30, 306459) A non violent organization implies the equal education
('78', 146, 12, 31, 306514) 1 The reference is to a letter from Manubehn Mashruwala to Gandhiji written at the instance of Gandhijis sister, Raliatbehn alias Gokibehn.
('78', 147, 0, 1, 306654) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 147, 1, 2, 306696) and therefore equal fitness of all units.
('78', 147, 1, 3, 306738) That we have not arrived at that stage shows our ignorance of the working of non violence.
('78', 147, 1, 4, 306829) AUTHORIZED AND UNAUTHORIZED STRIKES
('78', 147, 2, 5, 306865) Q. In your leading article 1 of March 30, you have hoped that passive satyagrahis will not interfere with the course of the struggle by precipitating strikes of labourers.
('78', 147, 2, 6, 307037) There is just this cryptic word precipitating and nothing more.
('78', 147, 2, 7, 307101) When I read it first, I did not particularly notice it.
('78', 147, 2, 8, 307157) But I had to do a lot of explaining later.
('78', 147, 2, 9, 307200) Unless a very careful reader or trained to understand your way of thought and expression, one is likely to go astray.
('78', 147, 2, 10, 307318) One may miss the force of the word precipitating and understand it as if you frowned upon all strikes of labourers.
('78', 147, 3, 11, 307434) With the recent Ahmedabad fight for a war bonus, no one would be entitled to regard you as an opponent of labourers strikes as such.
('78', 147, 3, 12, 307567) The strike in Ahmedabad was indeed averted, but you had approved of it and the workers realized their demands.
('78', 147, 3, 13, 307678) The work in Ahmedabad was done methodically.
('78', 147, 3, 14, 307723) There was proper presentation and working out of labourers demands, completing of arbitration, full notice and balloting of the over hundred thousand votes on the question of the strike.
('78', 147, 3, 15, 307910) I believe that, if after such methodical work a strike cannot be averted, you will approve of it and only assure yourself that there is no violence.
('78', 147, 3, 16, 308059) A. You are right.
('78', 147, 3, 17, 308077) I consider myself to be an expert in organized strikes.
('78', 147, 3, 18, 308133) My first successful attempt was made in South Africa under most adverse circumstances.
('78', 147, 3, 19, 308220) I improved the technique in Ahmedabad.
('78', 147, 3, 20, 308259) I do not claim to have reached perfection.
('78', 147, 3, 21, 308302) I know that strikes can be made irresistible.
('78', 147, 3, 22, 308348) I have discountenanced only unauthorized strikes.
('78', 147, 3, 23, 308398) The Congress has not gained control over labour.
('78', 147, 3, 24, 308447) Some Congressmen have.
('78', 147, 3, 25, 308470) Almost all the strike leaders have their own methods.
('78', 147, 3, 26, 308524) All of them are not non violent.
('78', 147, 3, 27, 308557) Some are ruled by selfish considerations.
('78', 147, 3, 28, 308599) Some others are unscrupulous.
('78', 147, 3, 29, 308629) What I, therefore, ask for is at least passive, if not active, co operation.
('78', 147, 3, 30, 308706) I shall not need strikes for the purpose of the struggle.
('78', 147, 3, 31, 308764) What shape mass civil disobedience will take, if it ever comes, I cannot say.
('78', 147, 3, 32, 308842) But I can say what it will never do if I have anything to do with it.
('78', 147, 3, 33, 308912) I know that, if the Congress had non violent control over all labour in India, the Congress could become far more powerful than it is today.
('78', 147, 3, 34, 309053) That control will come when the congress has one policy about labour and has enough workers to give effect to it.
('78', 147, 3, 35, 309167) UNTOUCHABILITY AND CONVERSION
('78', 147, 4, 36, 309197) Q. If the object of the Congress in the liquidation of untouchability is to give Harijans a status of equality with the rest, is this not achieved by their
('78', 147, 5, 37, 309353) 1 Vide Every Congress Committee a Satyagraha Committee, 25 3 1940.
('78', 148, 0, 1, 309420) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 149
('78', 148, 1, 2, 309465) conversion to Islam ?
('78', 148, 1, 3, 309487) Why does the Independence Pledge allocate the programme of the removal of untouchability to the Hindus only ?
('78', 148, 1, 4, 309597) Does this not show that Congress is anxious to maintain a Hindu majority and therefore denies to the Mussalmans their right of conversion ?
('78', 148, 1, 5, 309737) A. Liquidation of untouchability cannot be attained by the conversion of untouchables to Islam or any other religion.
('78', 148, 1, 6, 309855) For it is the so called caste Hindu who has to rid himself of the sin of untouchability.
('78', 148, 1, 7, 309944) He can wash away the stain only by doing justice, however tardy, to the outcaste.
('78', 148, 1, 8, 310026) You will thus see why Muslims are not invited by the Congress to share the burden with the Hindus.
('78', 148, 1, 9, 310125) They have committed no sin against the untouchables.
('78', 148, 1, 10, 310178) I cannot prevent you from looking at a simple but necessary social reform as a political dodge to maintain a majority.
('78', 148, 1, 11, 310297) Tens of thousands of Hindus who are doing penance have no thought of majority.
('78', 148, 1, 12, 310376) All they want is to do justice to those whom, under the guise of religion, caste Hindus have reduced to a state worse than slavery.
('78', 148, 1, 13, 310508) Lastly, you are hopelessly wrong in suggesting that the Congress denies the right to Muslims to convert untouchables.
('78', 148, 1, 14, 310626) The Congress cannot prevent anybody from doing conversion work.
('78', 148, 1, 15, 310690) Whether you will exercise the right in the right manner or wrong is for you to consider.
('78', 148, 1, 16, 310779) SEVAGRAM, April 15, 1940 Harijan, 20 4 1940

('78', 149, 26, 35, 312823) I have no reason to doubt their accuracy.
('78', 149, 26, 36, 312865) The facts are these.
('78', 149, 26, 37, 312886) There was a khadi exhibition held during the National Week by known workers.
('78', 149, 26, 38, 312963) The promoters had arranged a series of lectures on the importance of khadi and other village

('78', 150, 1, 4, 313603) The authorities served a notice that a flag having been erected on the rampart of the fort had caused annoyance to some of His Majestys subjects and should be hauled down within an hour.
('78', 150, 1, 5, 313790) The promoters claimed that the ground was under municipal jurisdiction, and that they had authority from the Municipality to hold the exhibition.
('78', 150, 1, 6, 313936) The protest was or no avail.
('78', 150, 1, 7, 313965) The flag was unceremoniously hauled down by the police and addresses prohibited.

('78', 150, 1, 10, 314256) An insult such as this can easily lead to unexpected results.
('78', 150, 1, 11, 314318) I suggest that the matter is one for the Central authority to investigate.
('78', 150, 1, 12, 314393) I hope that the Central authority does not want to provoke a clash which is highly likely if incidents like the Ajmer one are repeated.
('78', 150, 1, 13, 314529) It would be deplorable if the non intended happened.

('78', 150, 1, 20, 314921) This flag represents unity,non violence and identification through the charkha of the highest with the lowliest in the land.
('78', 150, 1, 21, 315046) Any insult to the flag must leave a deep scar on an Indian breast.
('78', 150, 1, 22, 315113) But today unity is lacking; the Muslim League has declared its hostility to the flag; those who honour it do not accept the authoritative implications of the flag.
('78', 150, 1, 23, 315277) And the nation is preparing for a vast struggle.
('78', 150, 1, 24, 315326) In a situation such as this I felt that the best course was to suppress the impulse to answer the insult.

('78', 150, 1, 27, 315749) It should be remembered that the exhibition had nothing whatsoever to do with the impending struggle.

('78', 151, 1, 2, 316101) 153. REPRESSION IN JODHPUR
('78', 151, 2, 3, 316128) News about repression in Jodhpur is disquieting.
('78', 151, 2, 4, 316177) The Jodhpur Lok Parishad, which according to the information in my possession has been before now held in respect by the local authorities, has suddenly been declared illegal.
('78', 151, 2, 5, 316353) Several prominent workers are under detention without trial.
('78', 151, 2, 6, 316414) Speeches and processions are banned.
('78', 151, 2, 7, 316451) What is worse is the speech delivered by the Maharaja Bahadur justifying the order.
('78', 151, 2, 8, 316535) It reads as if a mountain was in labour.
('78', 151, 2, 9, 316576) The following are extracts 1 form the report of the speech:
('78', 151, 3, 10, 316636) .Member of the Lok Parishad have recently become increasingly violent in their denunciations of all established order and traditions.
('78', 151, 3, 11, 316770) The members of this party ask us to believe that the sole panacea for the many diverse affictions.
('78', 151, 3, 12, 316869) is to vote for and place ourselves unreservedly in the hands of the Lok Parishad.
('78', 151, 3, 13, 316951) We are asked t believe that with the advent to power of the Lok Parishad there will be created a new heaven and a new earth.
('78', 151, 3, 14, 317076) And I, the Maharaja of Jodhpur, am desired to place the destinies of my house and my people in the hands of the Lok Parishad in order that peace may reign and freedom be enjoyed by all.
('78', 151, 4, 15, 317262) This is indeed a tall order and a bold demand.
('78', 151, 4, 16, 317309) the Lok Parishad consists mainly of inexperienced young men, men who do not appear to have achieved much success in their various vocations.
('78', 151, 5, 17, 317450) They show no sign whatever of any co operative spirit.
('78', 151, 6, 18, 317505) I do not consider it consistent with my duty, as a loyal ally of the British Government, to allow a groundless political agitation to grow and spread in my state in time of war; nor am I prepared any longer to allow an open campaign of subversive agitation manifestly designed to encourage our peasantry to revolt and to corrupt our youth.
('78', 151, 6, 19, 317845) It seems that the voice is the Maharajas but the hand that has prepared it is not his.
('78', 151, 6, 20, 317932) The speech consists of palpable exaggerations.
('78', 151, 6, 21, 317979) The Parishad has more than 30 branches in the State and has many experienced men as mambers.
('78', 151, 6, 22, 318072) I have seen correspondence in which their co operation has been desired and sought for.
('78', 151, 6, 23, 318160) The Lok Parishad has never put forth the claim attributed to it in the quotations.
('78', 151, 6, 24, 318243) It has responsible government within the State as its goal.
('78', 151, 6, 25, 318303) It has carried on agitation in the recognized manner.
('78', 151, 6, 26, 318357) I suggest that it is highly undignified for the advisers of the Maharaja to put into his mouth
('78', 151, 7, 27, 318452) 1 Of which only excerpts are reproduced here.
('78', 152, 0, 1, 318498) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 153
('78', 152, 1, 2, 318543) words that have no correlation to facts.
('78', 152, 1, 3, 318584) They have not hesitated even to drag the war and the alliance with Britain to justify the high handed action adopted towards the Parishad.
('78', 152, 1, 4, 318723) The Parishad, I am sure, will come out unscathed, if the workers can stand the test of self suffering.
('78', 152, 1, 5, 318826) Those who are imprisoned will be the salt and saviours of Jodhpur, for they will be trusted by the people as their real servants.

('78', 154, 1, 2, 321385) 157. DISCUSSION AT CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING
('78', 154, 2, 3, 321439) WARDHA [April 15/19, 1940] 1
('78', 154, 3, 4, 321468) Discussing the present political situation Gandhiji said that the letters he was receiving from all over the country indicated that there was no atmosphere for the starting of the struggle.
('78', 154, 3, 5, 321658) In Bengal and the Punjab, the struggle would not be against the British but against the respective ministries.
('78', 154, 3, 6, 321769) People asked him what next.
('78', 154, 3, 7, 321797) Some wanted to know if they were to leave their Government jobs and join in the preparation.
('78', 154, 3, 8, 321890) He was telling everybody to keep ready.
('78', 154, 3, 9, 321930) He was in no hurry.
('78', 154, 3, 10, 321950) Some people asked if he would commence the struggle in spite of the attitude of the Muslim League and the Khaksars.
('78', 154, 4, 11, 322066) Congressmen, he continued, told him that there was neither honesty nor discipline in the Congress and there was no belief in the constructive programme.
('78', 154, 4, 12, 322219) All this did not encourage him to issue the word of command for the struggle.
('78', 154, 4, 13, 322297) Talking of the internationals situation, he said, that did not affect him.
('78', 154, 4, 14, 322372) His gaze was centred on the internal situation and that was not hopeful.
('78', 154, 4, 15, 322445) Some people asked if he would sit still and allow the present opportunity to pass by.
('78', 154, 4, 16, 322531) His reply was that he was helpless unless conditions precedent were fulfilled.
('78', 154, 5, 17, 322610) Shri Jawaharlal said that all this was known at the time of the Ramgarh resolution.
('78', 154, 5, 18, 322694) Nothing new had happened since.
('78', 154, 5, 19, 322726) That resolution contemplated struggle if there was goading from the Government.
('78', 154, 5, 20, 322806) He asked if Gandhiji was contemplating a non mass struggle.
('78', 154, 6, 21, 322866) Gandhijis reply was that he did not feel that Government was bent upon goading.
('78', 154, 6, 22, 322946) If he felt that he would not wait for numbers he would begin with a few.
('78', 154, 6, 23, 323019) Participation of even 50,000 satyagrahis would not make the action a mass struggle.
('78', 154, 6, 24, 323103) Mass meant indefinite numbers.
('78', 154, 6, 25, 323134) But if 50,000 satyagrahis offered themselves, it might mean that the door for mass civil disobedience had been opened.
('78', 154, 7, 26, 323253) Shri Jawaharlalji said that the goading at present might not be sufficient but it would go on increasing.
('78', 154, 7, 27, 323359) Should the nation not prepare to resist it?
('78', 154, 7, 28, 323403) He was not prepared to say that action might be immediately precipitated.
('78', 154, 7, 29, 323477) But it was a fact that the country was being pushed back.
('78', 154, 7, 30, 323535) He asked Gandhiji what the latter would do if he got 50,000 satyagrahis.

('78', 159, 14, 27, 332047) 165. INTERVIEW TO THE NEW YORK TIMES
('78', 159, 15, 28, 332084) [Before April 22, 1940] 2
('78', 159, 16, 29, 332110) Q. I have heard it said on behalf of Britain, We cannot say what the new world is going to be at the end of the war; the Indian problem cannot be isolated from world problems; .
('78', 159, 16, 30, 332288) Dominion Status under existing circumstances is the highest we
('78', 159, 17, 31, 332351) 1 Vide "Danger Signal", 16 4 1940
('78', 159, 18, 32, 332385) 2 The report by Amrit Kaur is dated Sevagram, April 22, 1940.
('78', 160, 0, 1, 332447) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 161
('78', 160, 1, 2, 332492) can offer India. You yourself have said,  Of what value is freedom to India if Britain and France fail? Can you throw some light on these points?
('78', 160, 2, 3, 332638) A. The legal status of India, whether it is Dominion Status or something else, can only come after the war.
('78', 160, 2, 4, 332746) It is not a question at present to decide whether India should be satisfied with Dominion Status for the time being.
('78', 160, 2, 5, 332863) The only question is what is the British policy?
('78', 160, 2, 6, 332912) Does Great Britain still hold the view that it is her sole right to determine the status of India or whether it is the sole right of India to make that determination?
('78', 160, 2, 7, 333079) If that question had not been raised, there would have been no discussion such as we are facing today.
('78', 160, 2, 8, 333182) The question having been raised and it was Indias right to raise it I was bound to throw in my weight, such as it is, with the Congress.
('78', 160, 2, 9, 333319) Nevertheless I can still repeat the question I put to myself immediately after the first interview with the Viceroy 1: Of what value is freedom to India if Britain and France fail? 2 If these powers fail, the history of Europe and the history of the world will be written in a manner no one can foresee.
('78', 160, 2, 10, 333623) Therefore my question has its own independent value.
('78', 160, 2, 11, 333676) The relevant point, however, is that by doing justice to India Britain might ensure victory of the Allies because their cause will then be acclaimed as righteous by the enlightened opinion of the world.
('78', 160, 3, 12, 333879) Q. Have you any views about world federation (Streits 3 scheme of 15 white democracies with India excluded at present) or about a federation of Europe with the British Commonwealth and again excluding India?
('78', 160, 3, 13, 334087) Would you advise India to enter such a larger federation so as to prevent a domination of the coloured races by the white?
('78', 160, 4, 14, 334210) A. Of course I would welcome a world federation of all the nations of the world.
('78', 160, 4, 15, 334291) A federation of the Western nations only will be an unholy combination and a menace to humanity.
('78', 160, 4, 16, 334388) In my opinion a federation excluding India is now an impossibility.
('78', 160, 4, 17, 334456) India has already passed the stage when she could be safely neglected.
('78', 160, 5, 18, 334527) Q. You have seen in your lifetime more devastation by war than there has been at any time in the worlds history.
('78', 160, 5, 19, 334640) And yet do you still believe in non violence as the basis of new civilization?
('78', 160, 5, 20, 334719) Are you satisfied that your own countrymen accept it
('78', 160, 6, 21, 334772) 1 This was on September 4, 1939. 2 Vide Statement to the Press, 5 9 1939. The text there reads; but what will it [the freedom of India] be worth if England and France fall? 3 C. K. Streit, an American journalist.
('78', 160, 6, 22, 334985) The reference is to a scheme he had propounded in Union Now.
('78', 161, 0, 1, 335046) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 161, 1, 2, 335088) without reservation?
('78', 161, 1, 3, 335109) You continue to harp on your conditions being fulfilled before starting civil disobedience.
('78', 161, 1, 4, 335201) Do you still hold to them?
('78', 161, 2, 5, 335228) A. You are right in pointing out that there is unheard of devastation going on in the world.
('78', 161, 2, 6, 335321) But that is the real moment for testing my faith in non violence.
('78', 161, 2, 7, 335387) Surprising as it may appear to my critics, my faith in non violence remains absolutely undimmed.
('78', 161, 2, 8, 335484) Of course non violence may not come in my lifetime in the measure I would like to see it come, but that is different matter.
('78', 161, 2, 9, 335609) It cannot shake my faith, and that is why I have become unbending so far as the fulfilment of my conditions prior to the starting of civil disobedience is concerned; because, at the risk of being the laughing stock of the whole world, I adhere to my belief that there is an unbreakable connection between the spinning wheel and non violence so far as India is concerned.
('78', 161, 2, 10, 335980) Just as there are signs by which you can recognize violence with the naked eye, so is the spinning wheel to me a decisive sign of non violence.
('78', 161, 2, 11, 336124) But nothing can deter me from working away in hope.
('78', 161, 2, 12, 336176) I have no other method for solving the many baffling problems that face India.

('78', 162, 2, 4, 337727) 166. QUESTION BOX BEEF
('78', 162, 3, 5, 337750) Q. The Muslim public need to be satisfied on a very important question.
('78', 162, 3, 6, 337822) Will the Muslims be allowed to eat their national food beef under a Hindu majority Government?
('78', 162, 3, 7, 337917) If you can satisfy the Muslims on this all important question, a great deal of knots will be solved.
('78', 162, 3, 8, 338018) You should give a straight answer to this question in your paper Harijain.
('78', 162, 4, 9, 338093) A. I do not know how this question arises.
('78', 162, 4, 10, 338136) For whilst Congressmen were in office they are not known to have interfered with the practice of beef eating by Muslims.
('78', 162, 4, 11, 338257) The question is also badly conceived.
('78', 162, 4, 12, 338295) There is no such thing as a Hindu majority Govern ment.
('78', 162, 4, 13, 338351) If a free India is to live at peace with herself, religious divisions must entirely give place to political divisions based on considerations other than religious.
('78', 162, 4, 14, 338515) Even as it is, though unfortunately religious differences loom large, most parties contain members drawn from all sects.
('78', 162, 4, 15, 338636) It is moreover not true to say that beef is the national food of Muslims.
('78', 162, 4, 16, 338710) In the first place the Muslims of India are not as yet a separate nation.
('78', 162, 4, 17, 338784) In the second, beef is not their ordinary good.
('78', 162, 4, 18, 338832) Their ordinary food is the same as that of the millions.
('78', 162, 4, 19, 338889) What is true is that there are very few Muslims who are vegetarians form a religious motive.
('78', 162, 4, 20, 338982) Therefore they will take meat, including beef, when they can get it.
('78', 162, 4, 21, 339051) But during the greater part of the year millions of Muslims, owing to poverty, go without meat of any kind.
('78', 162, 4, 22, 339159) These are facts.
('78', 162, 4, 23, 339176) But the theoretical question demands a clear answer.
('78', 162, 4, 24, 339229) As a Hindu, a con firmed vegetarian, and a worshipper of the cow whom I regard with the same veneration as I regard my mother (alas, no more on this earth), I maintain that Muslims should have full freedom to slaughter cows, if they wish, subject of course to hygienic restrictions and in a manner not to wound the susceptibilities of their Hindu neighbours.
('78', 162, 4, 25, 339588) Fullest recognition off freedom to the Muslims to slaughter cows is indispensable for communal harmony, and is the only way of saving the cow.
('78', 162, 4, 26, 339731) In 1921 thousands of cows were saved by the sole and willing effort of Muslims themselves.
('78', 162, 4, 27, 339822) In spite of the black clouds hanging over our heads.
('78', 162, 4, 28, 339875) I refuse to give up the hope that they will disperse and that we shall have communal peace in this unhappy land.
('78', 162, 4, 29, 339988) If I am
('78', 163, 0, 1, 339996) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 163, 1, 2, 340038) asked for proof, I must answer that my hope is based on faith and faith demands no proof.
('78', 163, 1, 3, 340128) DEATH SENTENCE
('78', 163, 2, 4, 340143) Q. Do you consider death sentence to be against your principle of ahimsa?
('78', 163, 2, 5, 340217) If so, what form of punishment would you advocate as a substitute in a free India?
('78', 163, 3, 6, 340300) A. I do regard death sentence as contrary to ahimsa.
('78', 163, 3, 7, 340353) Only he takes life who gives it.
('78', 163, 3, 8, 340386) All punishment is repugnant to ahimsa.
('78', 163, 3, 9, 340425) Under a State governed according to the principles of ahimsa, therefore, a murdered would be sent to a penitentiary and there given every chance of reforming himself.
('78', 163, 3, 10, 340592) All crime is a kind of disease and should be treated as such.
('78', 163, 3, 11, 340654) GODS WILL
('78', 163, 4, 12, 340664) Q. How can an ordinary man distinguish between Gods will and his own will?
('78', 163, 5, 13, 340739) A. By not regarding anything as Gods will unless he has positive proof to the contrary.
('78', 163, 5, 14, 340827) Not every person can know Gods will.
('78', 163, 5, 15, 340864) Proper training is necessary to attain the power to know Gods will.
('78', 163, 5, 16, 340932) an offence against congress
('78', 163, 6, 17, 340960) Q. Some of the Congress committees here in Adampur Doaba during the last Independence Day celebrations got prepared national flags of uncertified khadi, and some of them got badge flags prepared from paper.
('78', 163, 6, 18, 341167) They sold these to raise funds.
('78', 163, 6, 19, 341199) When questioned they pleaded that they wanted funds for the Congress and could not afford to sell badge flags made out of khadi for one piece each and still retain something for themselves.
('78', 163, 6, 20, 341389) At some places I even found national flags hoisted which were of mill cloth and even without the spinning wheel.
('78', 163, 6, 21, 341502) I personally feel that the spinning wheel and khadi are the very soul of our flag; and a national flag which is printed on uncertified khadi and without the spinning wheel mark on it, or a paper flag cannot be called a national flag.
('78', 163, 7, 22, 341736) A. Your objection is sound.
('78', 163, 7, 23, 341764) The Congress committees who used as national flags paper flags or those which were made of mill cloth or uncertified khadi or without the charkha, committed an offence against the Congress.
('78', 163, 7, 24, 341954) The betrayed little regard for the flag.
('78', 163, 7, 25, 341995) Any rag cannot be used as flag.
('78', 163, 7, 26, 342027) It has to conform to the prescribed pattern.
('78', 163, 7, 27, 342072) If we do not respect our own flag, we have no right to expect others to do so.
('78', 163, 7, 28, 342151) You have made out a case for the central office having a stock of flags of variety of sizes.
('78', 163, 7, 29, 342244) Nobody should be permitted to use unauthorized flags as national flags.

('78', 164, 1, 2, 342405) 167. WHAT BIG EMPLOYERS CAN DO
('78', 164, 2, 3, 342436) Shri Vthaldas Jerajani sends me the following 1 from Shri Shantikumar 2 of the Scindia House:
('78', 164, 3, 4, 342530) During the National Week every effort will be made to sell khadi.
('78', 164, 3, 5, 342596) Then why not approach the big offices.
('78', 164, 3, 6, 342635) to buy khadi for peons dresses?
('78', 164, 3, 7, 342667) Last year the Scindia Company provided khadi uniforms for the peons, and this year also we are going to have the same.
('78', 164, 3, 8, 342786) I am trying to push khadi uniforms in other Associated Companies of the Scindia Company.
('78', 164, 4, 9, 342875) I am also trying to push the use of handmade paper in the office of the Scindia Company.
('78', 164, 4, 10, 342964) I have no hesitation in whole heartedly endorsing the suggestion made by Shri Shantikumar.
('78', 164, 4, 11, 343055) I would go a step further.
('78', 164, 4, 12, 343082) In order that the peons who have willy nilly to wear uniforms provided for them may not feel any inferiority, the big office staff should set the example by themselves voluntarily using khadi for their garments.
('78', 164, 4, 13, 343294) Khadi is one of the greatest levellers.
('78', 164, 4, 14, 343334) The peons should be able to take pride in their uniforms.
('78', 164, 4, 15, 343392) This they will only do when they know that their employers use the same material as that of which their uniforms are made.
('78', 164, 4, 16, 343515) The greater the approach on the part of employers to their employees, the greater the possibility of a peaceful solution of the difficult problem of class conflict.
('78', 164, 4, 17, 343680) I therefore hope that Shri Shantikumars effort will be appre ciated by the other employers.
('78', 164, 4, 18, 343772) Indeed the idea should be taken up by all public institutions such as hospitals, studentss hostels, etc.
('78', 164, 4, 19, 343877) The use of handmade paper is a less difficult problem.
('78', 164, 4, 20, 343932) For good handmade paper is any day more artistic than and superior to the ordinary mill paper, and there is not the same difference in the prices of the two varieties as in the case of khadi and millmade cloth.
('78', 164, 4, 21, 344143) The big houses owe it to the millions to use as many handmade articles as is possible for them to do.

('78', 165, 1, 2, 344391) 168. ABOUT ZAMINDARS
('78', 165, 2, 3, 344412) A first class Deccan Sardar propounds the following conun drums: 1
('78', 165, 3, 4, 344479) You say, on page 442 lines 4 6 of Harijan of 10th February, 2 that you put Europeans on the same footings as big zamindars and capitalists.
('78', 165, 3, 5, 344619) I presume that you include in the general word zamindars, inamdars 3 , talukdars and big landholders.
('78', 165, 4, 6, 344721) 1. Will you be pleased to say whether you remember and realise the fact that Europeans are foreigners and their earnings and profits go out of the country to enrich other nations and make them more powerful instruments to exploit India; while zamindars and inamdars.
('78', 165, 4, 7, 344988) are Indian.
('78', 165, 4, 8, 345000) and all their earnings and savings and even their extravagance will remain in this country.
('78', 165, 4, 9, 345092) Many of these people have national interest fully at heart.
('78', 165, 5, 10, 345152) 2. What are the differences between a nationalist zamindar and a nationalist non zamindar, in your opinion?
('78', 165, 6, 11, 345260) 3. What exact position do you assign to zamindars and inamdars, and the capitalists in a free and independent India?
('78', 165, 7, 12, 345377) 4. Have the zamindars and inamdars and capitalists any place in the present Congress, consistent with their limitations and commitments?
('78', 165, 8, 13, 345514) Answers: 1. I make no difference between Europeans and Indians, if the former conform to the laws of free India.
('78', 165, 8, 14, 345627) I cannot, consistently with my views on non violence.
('78', 165, 8, 15, 345681) Under my scheme European settlers will not be allowed to exploit the country as most of them are doing today.
('78', 165, 8, 16, 345791) Patriots will have had their reward in the shape of freedom of their country.
('78', 165, 8, 17, 345869) They are no patriots who are working with selfish personal ends in view.
('78', 165, 8, 18, 345942) If we create a State based on pure justice, real equality and genuine brotherhood, Europeans will cease to be foreig ners.
('78', 165, 8, 19, 346065) They will take pride in pooling their talents for the sole good of the country of their adoption.
('78', 165, 8, 20, 346163) I gladly acknowledge the fact that there are many inamdars, zamindars and other capitalists who are as patriotic as any Congress men.
('78', 165, 8, 21, 346297) 2. A nationalist zamindar will try to live like a non zamindar.
('78', 165, 8, 22, 346361) He will regard his tenants as his co proprietors; in other words, he will
('78', 165, 9, 23, 346435) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('78', 165, 9, 24, 346472) 2 Vide Statement to the Press, 6 2 1940.
('78', 165, 10, 25, 346513) 3 Holders of lease free land
('78', 166, 0, 1, 346542) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 167
('78', 166, 1, 2, 346587) hold his zamindari in trust for his tenants taking a moderate commission for the use of his labours and capital.
('78', 166, 1, 3, 346700) A nationalist non zamindar will not regard the zamindaras his natural enemy but will seek redress of his wrongs by the process of conversion.
('78', 166, 1, 4, 346842) I have shown before now that this is not a long drawn out agony.
('78', 166, 1, 5, 346907) 3. This is answered in the foregoing.
('78', 166, 1, 6, 346945) Antagonism between the classes will be removed.
('78', 166, 1, 7, 346993) I do not envisage a dead and artificial level among the people.
('78', 166, 1, 8, 347057) There will be a variety among them as there is among the leaves of a tree.
('78', 166, 1, 9, 347132) There will certainly be no have note, no unemployment, and no disparity between classes and masses such as we see today.
('78', 166, 1, 10, 347253) I have no doubt whatsoever that if non violence in its full measure becomes the policy of the State, we shall reach essential equality without strife.
('78', 166, 1, 11, 347404) 4. All who subscribe to the simple creed of the Congress can join it.
('78', 166, 1, 12, 347474) As a matter of fact there are many moneyed members of the Congress.
('78', 166, 1, 13, 347542) To quote only one instance, Jamnalalji is a capitalist and he is a member of the Working Committee.
