('78', 169, 0, 1, 351335) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 169, 1, 2, 351377) 174. CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('78', 169, 2, 3, 351401) The Working Committee 1 advisedly passed no startling or new resolution this time.
('78', 169, 2, 4, 351484) For there was no programme before them.
('78', 169, 2, 5, 351524) That of civil disobedience has to be evolved by me.
('78', 169, 2, 6, 351576) But the Committee had useful discussions on many points arising out of the contemplated movement.
('78', 169, 2, 7, 351674) I propose to give the readers the gist of what I told the members of the Committee, with the necessary amplification.
('78', 169, 3, 8, 351792) Civil disobedience in the face of the lawlessness that prevails in the country will easily pass for the same unless it is beyond doubt recognized as something different in kind from the prevailing brand.
('78', 169, 3, 9, 351996) Thus the Khaksar defiance is admittedly and openly violent.
('78', 169, 3, 10, 352056) 2 The kisans who held up the train between Gaya and Kiul were violent under cover of non violence.
('78', 169, 3, 11, 352155) They were doubt guilty according to the non violent conception.
('78', 169, 3, 12, 352219) For they are supposed to be Congressmen.
('78', 169, 3, 13, 352260) To hold up a train is disobedience without doubt.
('78', 169, 3, 14, 352310) And so far as the Congress is concerned, according to the Ramgarh resolution, 3 Con gressmen may not resort to civil disobedience singly or in groups without my permission.
('78', 169, 3, 15, 352483) I have already said that Prof.
('78', 169, 3, 16, 352514) Rangas dis obedience was also not civil.
('78', 169, 3, 17, 352555) 4 His friends have asked me to withdraw my criticism.
('78', 169, 3, 18, 352609) I claim to be a special friend of his.
('78', 169, 3, 19, 352648) We became friends probably before the protesters knew him.
('78', 169, 3, 20, 352707) And it is because he is such a close friend that I condemned his action without mincing words.I am sure he will not misunderstand me.
('78', 169, 3, 21, 352841) In any event when a man of his learning chooses deliberately to commit an act of indiscipline it must come to me as a warning against any hasty action.
('78', 169, 4, 22, 352993) Now civil disobedience, if it is really civil, must appear so even to the opponent.
('78', 169, 4, 23, 353077) He must feel that the resistance is not intended to do him any harm.
('78', 169, 4, 24, 353146) At the present moment the average Englishman thinks that non violence is merely a cloak.
('78', 169, 4, 25, 353235) The Muslim Leaguers think that civil disobedience is aimed at them more than at the British.
('78', 169, 4, 26, 353328) I protest
('78', 169, 5, 27, 353338) 1 The Working Committee met at Wardha from April 15 to 19. 2 Violent and widespread clashes, inspired by the Khaksars, had been taking place in the Punjab.For further comment by Gandhiji, vide All on Trial, 8 4 1940.
('78', 169, 6, 28, 353555) 3 ibid.
('78', 169, 7, 29, 353563) 4 Vide Notes, 9 4 1940
('78', 170, 0, 1, 353586) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 171
('78', 170, 1, 2, 353631) with all the strength at my command that, so far as I am concerned, I have no desire whatsoever to embarrass the British, especially at a time when it is a question of life and death with them.
('78', 170, 1, 3, 353825) All I want the Con gress to do through civil disobedience is to deny the British Govern ment the moral influence which the Congress co operation would give.
('78', 170, 1, 4, 353982) The material resources of India and her man power are already being exploited by the British Government by reason or their control of the whole of this subcontinent.
('78', 170, 1, 5, 354148) If by civil disobedience the Congress has no desire to embarrass the British people, it has still less to embarrass the Muslim League.
('78', 170, 1, 6, 354283) And I can say this on behalf of the Congress with far greater assu rance than I can with regard to the British.
('78', 170, 1, 7, 354395) Working in the midst of suspicion and terrible misrepresentation.
('78', 170, 1, 8, 354461) on the one hand and the prevailing lawlessness outside and inside the Congress on the other, I have to think a thousand times before embarking on civil disobe dience.
('78', 170, 1, 9, 354628) So far as I can see at present mass civil disobedience is most unlikely.
('78', 170, 1, 10, 354701) The choice lies between individual civil disobedience on a large scale, very restricted, or confined only to me.
('78', 170, 1, 11, 354814) In every case there must be the backing of the whole of the official congress organization and the millions who, though not on the Congress register, have always supported the organization with their mute but most effective co operation.
('78', 170, 1, 12, 355052) I have repeatedly shown in these columns that the most effective and visible co operation which all Congressmen and the mute millions can show is by not interfering with the course civil disobedience may take and by themselves spinning and using khadi to the exclusion of all other cloth.
('78', 170, 1, 13, 355341) If it is allowed that there is a meaning in people wearing primroses on Primrose Day, surely there is much more in people using a particular kind of cloth and giving a particular kind of labour to the cause they hold dear.
('78', 170, 1, 14, 355564) From their compliance with the khadi test I shall infer that they have shed untouchability, and that they have nothing but brotherly feeling towards all without distinction of race, colour or creed.
('78', 170, 1, 15, 355763) Those who will do this are as much satyagrahis as those who will be singled out for civil disobedience.
('78', 170, 1, 16, 355867) SEVAGRAM, April 23,1940

('78', 171, 2, 3, 355983) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, April 24, 1940
('78', 171, 3, 4, 356016) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW,
('78', 171, 4, 5, 356038) This is going to be a complaining letter.
('78', 171, 4, 6, 356080) I was tempted to write to the Press on Lord Zetlands speech 1 .
('78', 171, 4, 7, 356144) But I restrained myself.
('78', 171, 4, 8, 356169) What I wanted to say was too serious to be given to the public.
('78', 171, 4, 9, 356233) Hence this letter.
('78', 171, 4, 10, 356252) I am carrying on my head a tremendous responsibility.
('78', 171, 4, 11, 356306) I want to avoid mistakes.
('78', 171, 4, 12, 356332) There is a ring of reluctance to [do] the right thing by India.
('78', 171, 4, 13, 356396) He may say we dont want to do the things by way of settlement, you will have to fight for it or take what we offer.
('78', 171, 4, 14, 356512) That would be a straight answer.

('78', 171, 4, 16, 356619) Hindu Muslim question, minorities and the like are common ground.
('78', 171, 4, 17, 356685) The Congress claims that they can be truly settled only by a constituent assembly or its equivalent.
('78', 171, 4, 18, 356786) On British admis sions, Princes are your creation.
('78', 171, 4, 19, 356837) That they were there before you came is true.

('78', 171, 5, 24, 357082) I feel sure this sample should enable you to infer the rest.

('78', 171, 6, 27, 357290) 1 Speaking in the House of Lords on April 18, Lord Zetland, the Secretary of State for India (1935 40), had said: A substantial measure of agreement among the communities of India is essential if the vision of united India is to become a reality .
('78', 171, 6, 28, 357538) But the fact of the matter is that the Congress Party has raised in the minds of many Muslims apprehensions which only they themselves can allay.

('78', 176, 1, 2, 362700) 184. AN ENGLISH SUGGESTION
('78', 176, 2, 3, 362727) An English friend writes thus: 1
('78', 176, 3, 4, 362760) It is still reasonable at present to proceed on the assumption that the Muslims would accept something a good deal less than Pakistan.
('78', 176, 3, 5, 362895) But the trouble is that the longer the time that elapses without any compromise solution being reached, the stronger and more insistent will be the cry for Pakistan, so that in the end civil war or partition will be the only alternatives.
('78', 176, 3, 6, 363134) I think the view held by some that there is nothing to be done but to wait upon events is fatal.
('78', 176, 3, 7, 363231) It is up to the British now to use all their powers of persuasion and statesmanship to compel the parties to settle.
('78', 176, 4, 8, 363348) The crux of the matter is who is to control power at the Centre Hindus or Muslims?
('78', 176, 4, 9, 363431) Over this the Congress must be prepared to make great concessions.
('78', 176, 4, 10, 363498) If the Congress do not recognize the quickly, I am afraid that partition will become, If not the only alternative, the best one.
('78', 176, 4, 11, 363627) Of course the British Government can do much.
('78', 176, 4, 12, 363673) They have done much by force.
('78', 176, 4, 13, 363703) They can make the parties come to a solution by force.
('78', 176, 4, 14, 363758) But they need not go so far.
('78', 176, 4, 15, 363787) What they have done hitherto is to prevent a proper solution.
('78', 176, 4, 16, 363849) In proof of my statement I commend the esteemed correspondent to the columns of Harijan.
('78', 176, 4, 17, 363938) The only thing the British Government have to do is to change their attitude.
('78', 176, 4, 18, 364016) Will they?
('78', 176, 4, 19, 364027) They can retain their hold on India by a policy of divide and rule.
('78', 176, 4, 20, 364095) A living unity between Muslims and Hindus is fraught with danger to their rule.
('78', 176, 4, 21, 364175) It would mean an end of it.
('78', 176, 4, 22, 364203) Therefore it seems to me that a true solution will come with the end of the rule, potentially if not in fact.
('78', 176, 4, 23, 364313) What can be done under the threat of Pakistan?
('78', 176, 4, 24, 364360) If it is not a threat but a desirable goal, why should it be prevented?
('78', 176, 4, 25, 364432) If it is undesirable and meant only for the Muslims to get more under its shadow, any solution would be an unjust solution.
('78', 176, 4, 26, 364556) It would be worse than no solution.
('78', 176, 4, 27, 364592) Therefore I am entirely for waiting till the menace it gone.
('78', 176, 4, 28, 364653) Indias independence is a living thing.
('78', 176, 4, 29, 364692) No make believe will suit.
('78', 176, 4, 30, 364719) The whole world is in the throes of a new birth.
('78', 176, 4, 31, 364768) Anything done for a temporary gain would be tantamount to an abortion.
('78', 176, 4, 32, 364839) I cannot think in terms of narrow Hinduism or narrow Islam.
('78', 176, 4, 33, 364899) I am wholly uninterested in a patch work solution.
('78', 176, 4, 34, 364950) India is a big
('78', 176, 5, 35, 364965) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('78', 177, 0, 1, 365002) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 177, 1, 2, 365044) country, a big nation composed of different cultures, which are tending to blend with one another, each complementing the rest.
('78', 177, 1, 3, 365172) If I must wait for the completion of the process, I must wait.
('78', 177, 1, 4, 365235) It may not be completed in my day.
('78', 177, 1, 5, 365270) I shall love to die in the faith that it must come in the fullness of time.
('78', 177, 1, 6, 365346) I should be happy to think that I had done nothing to hamper the process.
('78', 177, 1, 7, 365420) Subject to this condition, I would do anything to bring about harmony.

('78', 177, 3, 15, 365901) 185. HINDU MUSLIM TANGLE
('78', 177, 4, 16, 365926) The partition proposal 1 has altered the face of the Hindu Muslim problem.
('78', 177, 4, 17, 366001) I have called it an untruth.
('78', 177, 4, 18, 366030) There can be no com promise with it.
('78', 177, 4, 19, 366067) At the same time I have said that, If the eight crores of Muslims desire it no power on earth can prevent it, notwithstanding opposition, violent or non violent It cannot come by honourable agreement.
('78', 177, 4, 20, 366268) That is the political aspect of it.
('78', 177, 4, 21, 366304) But what about the religious and the moral which are greater than the political?
('78', 177, 4, 22, 366385) For at the bottom of the cry for partition is the belief that Islam is an exclusive brother hood, and anti Hindu.
('78', 177, 4, 23, 366499) Whether it is against other religions it is not stated.
('78', 177, 4, 24, 366555) The newspaper cuttings in which partition is preached describe Hindus as practically untouchables.
('78', 177, 4, 25, 366654) Nothing good can come out of Hindus or Hinduism.
('78', 177, 4, 26, 366703) To live under Hindu rule is a Sin.
('78', 177, 4, 27, 366738) Even joint Hindu Muslim rule is not to be thought of.
('78', 177, 4, 28, 366792) The cuttings show that Hindu and Muslims are already at war with one another and that they must prepare for the final tussle.
('78', 177, 4, 29, 366918) Time was when Hindus thought that Muslims were the natural enemies of Hindus.
('78', 177, 4, 30, 366996) But as is the case with Hinduism, ultimately it

('78', 178, 1, 4, 367426) As if nemesis had overtaken Hinduism, the Muslim League started the same game and taught that there could be no blending of the two cultures.
('78', 178, 1, 5, 367568) In this connection I have just read a booklet by Shri Atulanand Chakrabarti which shows that ever since the contact of Islam with Hinduism there has been an attempt on the part of the best minds of both to see the good points of each other, and to emphasize inherent similarities rather than seeming dissimilarities.

('78', 181, 3, 9, 374881) 187. WANTON DESTRUCTION IN BIDAR
('78', 181, 4, 10, 374914) A correspondent is grieved that I have been silent about the shocking tragedy in Bidar (Hyderabad State).
('78', 181, 4, 11, 375020) 1 I have before now said in another connection that because I say nothing in public about certain wrongs it is not be thought that I am oblivious of them or that I am doing nothing.
('78', 181, 4, 12, 375202) I must be allowed to judge what is best under given circumstances.
('78', 181, 4, 13, 375269) If all I have heard about Bidar (not all has been published in the papers) is true, nothing quite like it has happened anywhere in all India.
('78', 181, 4, 14, 375411) If Hyderabad State is not to give over to lawlessness and Hindu life and property not rendered valueless, there should be a thorough and impartial judicial inquiry commanding confidence, and full compensation should be given to those who are rendered suddenly homeless.
('78', 181, 4, 15, 375681) It is to be hoped that Muslim opinion outside Hyderabad will ask for full investigation into the happenings.
('78', 181, 4, 16, 375790) SEVAGRAM, April 30, 1940

('78', 181, 6, 18, 375833) 188. QUESTION BOX
('78', 181, 7, 19, 375851) NO CONFUSION
('78', 181, 8, 20, 375864) Q. There is still a lot of confusion in the public mind about the Indian situation.
('78', 181, 8, 21, 375948) How can one remove it?
('78', 181, 9, 22, 375971) A. Confusion should have been removed as soon as the popular ministers resigned.
('78', 181, 9, 23, 376052) They were the chosen representatives of the people.
('78', 181, 9, 24, 376104) They had applied themselves to their work with amazing ind ustry and efficiency which won the unstinted praise of the Governors.
('78', 181, 9, 25, 376233) They took no rest themselves and allowed none to their subordinates.
('78', 181, 9, 26, 376302) They had set a definite programme before themselves which would
('78', 181, 10, 27, 376366) 1 The reference is to communal riots in Bidar.
('78', 181, 10, 28, 376413) Vide also "Bidar", 28 5 1940.
('78', 182, 0, 1, 376443) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 183
('78', 182, 1, 2, 376488) have improved the condition of the masses.
('78', 182, 1, 3, 376531) It must have cost them a lot to give up office.
('78', 182, 1, 4, 376579) But they found to their amazement that Provin cial Autonomy, Which sir Samuel Hoare had declared from the house tops to be real and complete, was reduced to a farce in the twinkling of an eye.
('78', 182, 1, 5, 376772) The popular ministers were to be mere registering officers to carry out the will of the central executive so far as war measures were concerned.
('78', 182, 1, 6, 376917) In this most vital matter they were not consulted formally or informally.
('78', 182, 1, 7, 376991) So the ministers had to resign.
('78', 182, 1, 8, 377023) This one act of theirs was complete in itself.
('78', 182, 1, 9, 377070) Its importance is not felt as it should be because the Congress is wedded to non violence.
('78', 182, 1, 10, 377161) CONGRESS NOT RESPONSIBLE
('78', 182, 2, 11, 377186) Q. Many people believe that the attitude of the congress has precipitated the Muslim League resolution about partitioning India.
('78', 182, 3, 12, 377315) A. I do not think so.
('78', 182, 3, 13, 377337) But if it has, it is a distinct gain.
('78', 182, 3, 14, 377375) It is good that what was in should come out.
('78', 182, 3, 15, 377420) It is easier now to deal with the problem.
('78', 182, 3, 16, 377463) It will solve itself.
('78', 182, 3, 17, 377485) One distinct gain is that nationalist Muslims have become awakened to a sense of their duty.
('78', 182, 3, 18, 377578) MUSLIM RULE = INDIAN RULE
('78', 182, 4, 19, 377604) Q. Would you prefer Muslim rule to British rule?
('78', 182, 5, 20, 377653) A. The question is badly put.
('78', 182, 5, 21, 377683) You, being British, cannot get out of the habit of thinking that India is fit only to be ruled by someone.
('78', 182, 5, 22, 377790) Muslim rule is equivalent to Indian rule.
('78', 182, 5, 23, 377832) You might as well ask me whether I would prefer Bengali or Maratha to British rule.
('78', 182, 5, 24, 377916) Maratha, Bengali, Sikh, Dravidian, Parsi, Christian(Indian), Muslim all will be Indian rule.
('78', 182, 5, 25, 378009) It makes no difference to me that some Muslims regard themselves as a separate nation.
('78', 182, 5, 26, 378096) It is enough for me that I do not consider them as such.
('78', 182, 5, 27, 378153) They are sons of the soil.
('78', 182, 5, 28, 378180) Muslims considered separately have eight crores of unarmed Muslims scattered over India to look to.
('78', 182, 5, 29, 378280) But you have the whole British nation and your army of occupation to look to.
('78', 182, 5, 30, 378358) You belong to the ruling race.
('78', 182, 5, 31, 378389) You are less than one hundred thousand in the midst of 350 millions over whom you rule.
('78', 182, 5, 32, 378477) It is a matter of shame both for you and us.
('78', 182, 5, 33, 378522) I need not weigh whose is the greater shame.
('78', 182, 5, 34, 378567) The sooner we get out of it the better for both of us.
('78', 182, 5, 35, 378622) You will now understand my answer when I say that I would any day prefer Muslim rule to British rule.
('78', 182, 5, 36, 378724) I have no doubt that, if
('78', 182, 6, 37, 378749) 1 Vide footnote 1 of Hindu Muslim Tangle, 29 4 1940.
('78', 183, 0, 1, 378802) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 183, 1, 2, 378844) British rule which divides us by favouring one or the other as it suits the Britishers were withdrawn today, Hindus and Muslims would forget their quarrels and live like brothers which they are.
('78', 183, 1, 3, 379039) But sup posing the worst happened and we had a civil war, it would last for a few days or months and we would settle down to business.
('78', 183, 1, 4, 379174) In status we are equal.
('78', 183, 1, 5, 379198) With you, it is different.

('78', 183, 1, 11, 379525) WHY THIS PARTIALITY?

('78', 183, 3, 39, 381027) A MUNICIPAL CHAIRMAN'S DUTY

('78', 184, 8, 18, 382261) 189. THE AJMER TROUBLE
('78', 184, 9, 19, 382284) Having published the gist 1 of the case of the Khadi exhibition organizers about the national flag incident, I am in duty bound to publish the following communiqu of the Commissioner of Ajmer Merwara on the incidents:
('78', 184, 10, 20, 382502) A feature of the celebration by the Ajmer Congress of what is known as
('78', 184, 11, 21, 382573) theNational Weekhas been an exhibition organized by a com mittee known
('78', 184, 12, 22, 382644) as the Khadi Gram Udyog Exhibition Committee.
('78', 184, 12, 23, 382690) For this a number of
('78', 184, 13, 24, 382711) temporary structures have been erected adjoining the fort on a plot of nazul
('78', 184, 14, 25, 382788) land, which is under the control of the municipal Committee.
('78', 184, 14, 26, 382849) Advantage was
('78', 184, 15, 27, 382863) taken of the fact that the exhibition attracted large crowds of people to hold
('78', 184, 16, 28, 382942) political meetings on a vacant plot between the exhibition grounds and the
('78', 184, 17, 29, 383017) entrance to the city kotwali.
('78', 184, 17, 30, 383047) At two of these meetings speeches of an
('78', 184, 18, 31, 383087) extremely objectionable character were delivered, and it was evident that the
('78', 184, 19, 32, 383165) organisers of the meetings who are members of the local Congress were
('78', 184, 20, 33, 383235) attempting under the pretext of promoting the use of khadi and village
('78', 184, 21, 34, 383306) industries in general to bring the Government into hatred and contempt.
('78', 184, 22, 35, 383378) fact that these seditious utterances were made at a place adjoining a barrack
('78', 184, 23, 36, 383456) 1 Vide Danger Signal, 16 4 1940
('78', 185, 0, 1, 383488) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 185, 1, 2, 383530) occupied by constables stationed at the kotwali was an additional
('78', 185, 2, 3, 383596) provocation.
('78', 185, 3, 4, 383609) Further, the organizers of the exhibition set up a flag staff on an
('78', 185, 4, 5, 383677) outlying bastion of the fort from which the Congress flag was flown.
('78', 185, 5, 6, 383746) bastion is on Government land and is a part of the kotwali Police Station.
('78', 185, 6, 7, 383821) Permission was neither sought for nor obtained for this act.
('78', 185, 6, 8, 383882) Apart from the
('78', 185, 7, 9, 383897) undesirability of a party emblem of this nature being displayed from a
('78', 185, 8, 10, 383968) Government building, the flying of the congress flag from the ramparts of an
('78', 185, 9, 11, 384045) ancient Moghul fort, which is a protected monument, caused grave offence to
('78', 185, 10, 12, 384121) certain sections of the public.
('78', 185, 11, 13, 384153) After satisfying grave himself by personal inspection as to the facts,
('78', 185, 12, 14, 384224) the Commissioner decided to issue two prohibitory order to prevent a breach
('78', 185, 13, 15, 384300) of public tranquillity.
('78', 185, 13, 16, 384324) The first order was addressed to the organizers of the
('78', 185, 14, 17, 384379) exhibition by name, and it directed them to remove the flag and flag staff
('78', 185, 15, 18, 384454) within one hour and to refrain from reerecting it within 400 yards of the fort
('78', 185, 16, 19, 384533) ramparts.
('78', 185, 16, 20, 384543) The second order was a general one prohibiting political meetings
('78', 185, 17, 21, 384609) under the Municipal limits for a period of ten days.
('78', 185, 17, 22, 384662) The issue of this order was
('78', 185, 18, 23, 384690) rendered necessary by the manner in which certain partisans of the Congress
('78', 185, 19, 24, 384766) had abused the opportunity which the holding of the Khadi Exhibition
('78', 185, 20, 25, 384835) presented.
('78', 185, 21, 26, 384846) As far as the first order is concerned, the individuals to whom it was
('78', 185, 22, 27, 384917) addressed intimated in writing their refusal to comply, whereupon the police
('78', 185, 23, 28, 384994) were directed to remove the flag and the flag staff.
('78', 185, 23, 29, 385047) Action is being taken
('78', 185, 24, 30, 385069) separately regarding the refusal of the organizers of the exhibition to comply
('78', 185, 25, 31, 385148) with the order.
('78', 185, 25, 32, 385164) If the above version is true, the case of the Exhibition Com mittee falls to the ground.
('78', 185, 25, 33, 385253) I may state that a correspondent claiming to impartial sends a letter supporting the version of the Ajmer autho rities.
('78', 185, 25, 34, 385373) I refrain from expressing any opinion till my investigation is complete.
('78', 185, 25, 35, 385446) One thing, however, is clear.
('78', 185, 25, 36, 385476) The Commissioner has done everything he can to incite the Muslims against the Exhibition Com mittee.
('78', 185, 25, 37, 385577) Prejudice against it peeps out through a portion of the com munique.
('78', 185, 25, 38, 385646) Even if the facts are as he has stated them, the Commis sioner could have avoided the inflammatory reference to the Moghul Fort.
('78', 185, 25, 39, 385775) He knew that the Exhibition Committee could have no inten tion of wounding Muslim susceptibilities.

('78', 191, 1, 15, 392718) BIDAR AND BIHAR

('78', 191, 2, 18, 392863) 1 Do you feel equally keenly if Muslims are ill treated as they were in Bihar.?

('78', 191, 3, 21, 393146) This has been my practice since the days of the Khilafat.
('78', 191, 3, 22, 393204) I have not always succeeded in finding the truth or giving satisfaction to the aggrieved parties that I had done my best.

('78', 191, 3, 28, 393928) My proposal in the case of Bidar should be applicable to all such cases.

('78', 192, 2, 3, 394147) As soon as I read the extraordinary communique 1 of the Commissioner of Ajmer, I asked for proof from the workers in Ajmer in support of their charges.
('78', 192, 2, 4, 394299) It seems to me that in every single particular the charges are supported by documentary evidence.
('78', 192, 2, 5, 394397) I have now in my possession copies of the relevant documents including a blue print showing where the so called Ajmer fort is, where the wall on whose bastion the Congress flag was flown is.

('78', 192, 2, 7, 394699) 2 From it, it would appear that the Commissioner is prejudiced against the Congress.

('78', 192, 2, 13, 395214) It is at present used for the kotwali etc.
('78', 192, 2, 14, 395257) It is undoubtedly a protected monument and in possession of the Government.
('78', 192, 2, 15, 395333) The outer wall is dilapidated and is included in the ground leased to the Municipal Council and is going to be demolished by them.
('78', 192, 2, 16, 395464) 6. There was no complaint brought before the workers against the hoisting of the flag on the wall.
('78', 192, 2, 17, 395563) It could give no offence to any body.
('78', 192, 2, 18, 395601) The Ajmer Council contains Muslim members.
('78', 192, 2, 19, 395644) The decision to give permission to hold the exhibition on the ground was unanimous.
('78', 192, 2, 20, 395728) Muslims freely visited the exhibition.
('78', 192, 2, 21, 395767) Well known Muslim attended the party given to Seth Jamnalalji 3 although they knew that the flag was hoisted on the outer wall.

('78', 195, 5, 20, 400879) 204. A ONE SIDED INQUIRY
('78', 195, 6, 21, 400904) I had hoped that I would not have to say anything on Justice Nagesvara Iyers report into the allegations of ill treatment of satya grahi prisoners in Mysore.
('78', 195, 6, 22, 401062) But the Press criticism of the action of the State Congress in abstaining fromparticipation in the inquiry demands an explanation from me.
('78', 195, 6, 23, 401201) If it was wrong for the State Congress not to participate in the inquiry, the blame was mine.
('78', 195, 6, 24, 401295) The inquiry was a result of Mahadev Desais visit to Mysore at the instance of the Dewan 3 and the formers confidential report to me of which a copy was given to the Dewan.
('78', 195, 6, 25, 401467) Mahadev Desai had recommended an open judicial inquiry presided over by a judge of known integrity brought from outside.
('78', 195, 6, 26, 401588) Instead there was only a departmental inquiry by a Mysore judge.
('78', 195, 6, 27, 401653) I have been for some time guiding the Mysore Con gress, and the Congress acted upon my advice in not leading evidence before a Mysore judge who could not, I felt, be wholly impartial in judging the conduct of officials with whom he must have come in close official contact.
('78', 195, 6, 28, 401927) It was too much to expect an impartial scrutiny
('78', 195, 7, 29, 401975) 1 Sharda G. Chokhawala's son 2 Vide "A Hideous Evil", 18 5 1940.
('78', 195, 8, 30, 402040) 3 Sir Mirza Ismail
('78', 196, 0, 1, 402059) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 197
('78', 196, 1, 2, 402104) by one who had risen to the rank of a judge from being a Govern ment official.
('78', 196, 1, 3, 402183) The allegations were of a most serious character, and they were repeated in the presence of Mahadev Desai and before officials occupying the positions of Deputy Commissioner, District Superinten dent of Police, Superintendent of Jail and so on.
('78', 196, 1, 4, 402428) Those who made the allegations were volunteers, not criminals, and a few of them held high social positions.
('78', 196, 1, 5, 402537) It is impossible to treat them as liars, as the report seems to have done.
('78', 196, 1, 6, 402612) I am not yet in possession of the Judges report.
('78', 196, 1, 7, 402661) What I have before me is a highly tendentious summary of the report published by Government, interspersed by Governments own statements of certain happenings and Justice Nagesvara Iyers comments on them in his report.
('78', 196, 1, 8, 402879) It passes comprehension that the inquiry was continued when the complainants refused to appear before the officer.
('78', 196, 1, 9, 402994) The judge should have dismissed the case for want to evidence.
('78', 196, 1, 10, 403057) How he could have arrived at definite conclusions in the absence of material evidence, it is difficult to say.
('78', 196, 1, 11, 403168) The judge admits that most of the persons who made accusations of assault and torture did not attempt to establish those charges, but that he had a large volume of oral and documentary evidence adduced before him.
('78', 196, 1, 12, 403382) What this docu mentary evidence was, we do no know.
('78', 196, 1, 13, 403434) The oral evidence was of people who had nothing to do with the inquiry but were dragged by the police before the judge to prove the Government case.
('78', 196, 1, 14, 403583) The judge says he has based his conclusions on such materials and broad probabilities, This is hardly the language of a judge.
('78', 196, 1, 15, 403710) No judge of integrity and impartiality would have cared to go into the extraneous evidence that Justice Nagesvara Iyer went into, and made uncalled for animadversions against satyagrahis for refusal to give evidence before him, when he knew that their reason in doing so was that they questioned the competence, independence and impartiality of the judge.
('78', 196, 1, 16, 404066) The paragraphs in the communique are devoted to proving that the leaders of the movement adopted questionable methods of sending out surreptitious letters from jails.
('78', 196, 1, 17, 404233) What this has to do with allegations of torture one is at a loss to know.
('78', 196, 1, 18, 404307) It would thus appear that, far from the inquiry being into any allegations by Congressmen, it became an inquiry into allegations by Government official which the judge has supported without giving those against whom the allegations were made an opportunity to rebut them.
('78', 197, 0, 1, 404579) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 197, 1, 2, 404621) My point, however, in referring to the unfortunate inquiry is that the Mysore Congress acted under my advice.
('78', 197, 1, 3, 404731) The judges biassed finding confirms me in the soundness of the opinion I gave them.
('78', 197, 1, 4, 404815) As satyagrahis, the members of the Mysore Congress were not interested in the guilty parties being condemned.
('78', 197, 1, 5, 404925) They were interested in the truth being known.

('78', 200, 2, 6, 410865) The moral weight of the Congress is at the disposal of the British people, the moment they act morally.
('78', 200, 2, 7, 410969) The Congress has nothing else to give.

('78', 200, 2, 9, 411098) I may have sympathy for my erring son but moral help is of no avail to him till he persists in his error.
('78', 200, 2, 10, 411204) The material help of Indian Britain gets whether we will of not.

('78', 205, 5, 16, 418680) 220. INTERVIEW TO THE TIMES OF INDIA 3
('78', 205, 6, 17, 418719) SEVAGRAM, May 9, 1940
('78', 205, 7, 18, 418741) Seated on a mat in his small barely furnished room, with a wet cloth wrapped
('78', 205, 8, 19, 418818) round his head, Mr. Gandhi carefully explained his viewpoint.
('78', 205, 8, 20, 418880) He spoke with great
('78', 205, 9, 21, 418900) earnestness.
('78', 205, 9, 22, 418913) I would welcome a settlement which ensures peace with honour.
('78', 205, 9, 23, 418975) The Viceroy knows I am always ready.
('78', 205, 9, 24, 419012) I am not averse to coming to terms with Britain on matters like defence and commercial interests, and I am fully prepared that these adjustments should be referred to a Constituent Assembly as part of an agreed settlement.
('78', 205, 10, 25, 419235) Mr. Gandhi went on to explain his attitude to the Constituent Assembly.
('78', 205, 11, 26, 419307) 1 Addressee's son 2 Address from the C. W. copy 3 This appeared in Harijan under the title An Important Interview.
('78', 206, 0, 1, 419422) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 207
('78', 206, 1, 2, 419467) I believe personally that it is the most satisfactory method of procedure; but dont forget that I preserve an open mind on the matter.
('78', 206, 1, 3, 419602) If some people hold that there are other forms of procedure which are more representative, I am willing to be convinced.
('78', 206, 1, 4, 419723) Today I say that the assembly should be elected on adult franchise, but here again my mind is open to alternative proposals provided these proposals have the backing of representative men.
('78', 206, 2, 5, 419912) If the Viceroy, asked the correspondent,  declares that he will summon a
('78', 206, 3, 6, 419985) conference of the best Englishmen and the best Indians, and if he further agrees that
('78', 206, 4, 7, 420071) its terms of reference will be to arrange for the establishment of self government
('78', 206, 5, 8, 420154) within the shortest period practicable, would you accept that gesture? Certainly, it will be acceptable.
('78', 206, 5, 9, 420259) In the preliminary conference it is necessary that the best Englishmen and the best Indians should meet to adjust their differences, but in the framing of the constitution only Indians must participate.
('78', 206, 5, 10, 420462) If the Viceroy is authorized to declare that His Majestys Government have definitely come to the conclusion that it is the sole right of India to determine the form of government under which she would live, and if with that end he summons a conference of the best Englishmen and the best Indiansthe latter elected according to an acceptable procedureto devise a method whereby a Constituent Assembly can be summoned for the purpose of framing a constitution and for solving all problems that may arise, I would accept the pro posal.
('78', 206, 5, 11, 420995) But I dont sense the proper atmosphere today.
('78', 206, 6, 12, 421041) Asked whether, if His Majestys Government summoned a conferences and
('78', 206, 7, 13, 421110) acted in good faith, Mr. Gandhi would be prepared to use his personal influence to
('78', 206, 8, 14, 421193) induce the Congress Ministers to return to office, the Mahatma quickly replied: Not unless there is a Hindu Muslim agreement.
('78', 206, 8, 15, 421319) I should wait.
('78', 206, 9, 16, 421334) As I said good bye, Mr. Gandhi chafed: You did not deserve the interview.
('78', 206, 9, 17, 421408) You brought a hot wind with you to Sevagram.
('78', 206, 10, 18, 421453) The temperature was 108. He laughed uproariously at my obvious retort: It is
('78', 206, 11, 19, 421530) an ill wind which brings no one any good.

('78', 208, 6, 15, 423107) 225. QUESTION BOX
('78', 208, 7, 16, 423125) DEMOCRACY AND NON VIOLENCE
('78', 208, 8, 17, 423152) Q. Why do you say,Democracy can only be saved through non violence?
('78', 208, 9, 18, 423220) A. Because democracy, so long as it is sustained by violence, cannot provide for or protect the weak.
('78', 208, 9, 19, 423322) My notion of democracy is that under it the weakest should have the same opportunity as the strongest.
('78', 208, 9, 20, 423425) That can never happen except through non violence.
('78', 208, 9, 21, 423476) No country in the world today shows any but patronizing regard for the weak.
('78', 208, 9, 22, 423553) The weakest, you say, go to the wall.
('78', 208, 9, 23, 423591) Take your own case.
('78', 208, 9, 24, 423611) Your land is owned by a few capitalist owners.
('78', 208, 9, 25, 423658) The same is true of South Africa.
('78', 208, 9, 26, 423692) These large holdings cannot be sustained except by violence, veiled if not open.
('78', 208, 9, 27, 423773) Western democracy, as it functions today, is diluted Nazism or Fascism.
('78', 208, 9, 28, 423845) At best it is merely a cloak to hide the Nazi and the Fascist tendencies of imperialism, Why is there the war today, if it is not for the satisfaction of the desire to share the spoils?
('78', 208, 9, 29, 424031) It was not through democratic methods that Britain bagged India.
('78', 208, 9, 30, 424096) What is the meaning of South African democracy?
('78', 208, 9, 31, 424144) Its very constitution has been drawn to protect the white man against the coloured man, the natural occupant.
('78', 208, 9, 32, 424254) Your own history is perhaps blacker still, in spite of what
('78', 208, 10, 33, 424314) 1 The Questioner was an American.
('78', 209, 0, 1, 424348) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 209, 1, 2, 424390) the Northern States did for the abolition of slavery.
('78', 209, 1, 3, 424444) The way you have treated the Negro presents a discreditable record.
('78', 209, 1, 4, 424512) And it is to save such democracies that the war is being fought!.
('78', 209, 1, 5, 424578) There is something very hypocritical about it.
('78', 209, 1, 6, 424625) I am thinking just now in terms of non violence and trying to expose violence in its nakedness.
('78', 209, 1, 7, 424721) India is trying to evolve true democracy, i.e., without violence.
('78', 209, 1, 8, 424787) Our weapons are those of satyagraha expressed through the charkha, the village industries, primary education through handicrafts, removal of untouchability, communal harmony, prohibition, and non violent organization of labour as in Ahmedabad.
('78', 209, 1, 9, 425031) These mean mass effort and mass education.
('78', 209, 1, 10, 425074) We have big agencies for conducting these activities.
('78', 209, 1, 11, 425128) They are purely voluntary, and their only sanction is service of the lowliest.
('78', 209, 1, 12, 425207) This is the permanent part of the non violent effort.
('78', 209, 1, 13, 425261) From this effort is created the capacity to offer non violent resistance called non co operation and civil disobedience which may culminate in mass refusal to pay rent and taxes.
('78', 209, 1, 14, 425440) As you know, we have tried non co operation and civil disobedience on a fairly large scale and fairly successfully.
('78', 209, 1, 15, 425556) The experiment has in it promise of a brilliant future.
('78', 209, 1, 16, 425612) As yet our resistance has been that of the weak.
('78', 209, 1, 17, 425661) The aim is to develop the resistance of the strong.
('78', 209, 1, 18, 425713) Your wars will never ensure safety for democracy.
('78', 209, 1, 19, 425763) Indias experiment can and will, if the people come up to the mark or, to put it another way, if God gives me the necessary wisdom and strength to bring the experiment to fruition.
('78', 209, 1, 20, 425943) HYPOCRISY
('78', 209, 2, 21, 425953) Q. I agree with you that those who do not believe in the tests laid down by you for enrolment as satyagrahis should not hold office in the Congress orga nization.
('78', 209, 2, 22, 426116) What is however, happening is that, while embargo upon disbelief has been effective, hypocrisy is enjoying a premium.
('78', 209, 2, 23, 426234) People who have nothing in common with your programme are coming forward with the satyagraha pledge 1 in order to capture power, their only qualification being lack of scruples.
('78', 209, 2, 24, 426412) Can you as general of the satyagraha army shut your eyes to this?
('78', 209, 2, 25, 426478) If not, what remedy do you propose?
('78', 209, 3, 26, 426514) A. I suppose Cowper not knowing how to deal with the hypocrite paid him a compliment by saying that hypocrisy was an ode to virtue 2 And so it is.
('78', 209, 3, 27, 426661) But the gentlemen whom you refer to will soon discover their error either by my sensing the hypocrisy and not
('78', 209, 4, 28, 426771) 1 Vide Appendix Satyagraha Pledge, before 1 6 1940.
('78', 209, 5, 29, 426823) 2 Rochefoucauld says: Hypocrisy is the homage paid by vice to virtue.
('78', 210, 0, 1, 426893) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 211
('78', 210, 1, 2, 426938) starting the struggle, or by their being tired of a role which requires labour from them.
('78', 210, 1, 3, 427028) Meanwhile I must take everyone at his or her word, and believe that those who have taken the pledge have done so in good faith.
('78', 210, 1, 4, 427156) I have no right to question anybodys motive unless I have proof positive to the contrary.
('78', 210, 1, 5, 427246) DEFENCE OF INDIA ACT
('78', 210, 2, 6, 427267) Q. The resolution 1 passed at Ramgarh says that Congressmen and those under the Congress influence cannot help in the prosecution of the War with men, money or material.
('78', 210, 2, 7, 427437) Every resolution of the Congress has to be explained to the people by Congressmen and Congress committees.
('78', 210, 2, 8, 427544) If we do that, we are sure to offend the provisions of the Defence of India Act, i.e., we will be committing an act of civil disobedience before you as general have given the word.
('78', 210, 2, 9, 427725) What are we to do under the circumstances?
('78', 210, 3, 10, 427768) A. I am not quite sure that you will commit an offence against the Defence of India Act merely by explaining the resolution to the people.
('78', 210, 3, 11, 427907) But you can easily put yourself under it by adding ginger to your explanation and delivering a first class harangue against British rule.
('78', 210, 3, 12, 428045) In your place I would not do it.
('78', 210, 3, 13, 428078) Sufficient education has been given to the people as to what British rule is.
('78', 210, 3, 14, 428156) But you should lay stress on what the people have to do to get out of foreign rule.
('78', 210, 3, 15, 428240) There fore everything depends upon how you say it.
('78', 210, 3, 16, 428291) You will offend against my instructions when you disobey explicit orders served upon you.
('78', 210, 3, 17, 428381) SELF DETERMINATION
('78', 210, 4, 18, 428400) Q. Are you right in conceding the right of self determination to Muslims in a matter so vitally affecting others also, viz., Hindus, Sikhs, etc.?
('78', 210, 4, 19, 428546) Supposing the majority of the Muslims decide in favour of partition in terms of the Muslim League resolution, what happens to the self determination of Hindus, Sikhs, etc., who will be minorities in the Muslim States?
('78', 210, 4, 20, 428764) If you go on like this, where will be the end to it?
('78', 210, 5, 21, 428817) A. Of course Hindus and Sikhs will have the same right.
('78', 210, 5, 22, 428873) I have simply said that there is no other no violent method of dealing with the problem.
('78', 210, 5, 23, 428962) If every component part of the nation claims the right of self determination for itself, there is no one nation and there is no independence.
('78', 210, 5, 24, 429104) I have already said that Pakistan is such an untruth that it cannot stand.
('78', 210, 5, 25, 429179) As soon as the authors begin to work it out, they will find that it is not practicable.
('78', 210, 5, 26, 429267) In any case mine is a personal opinion.
('78', 210, 6, 27, 429307) 1 Vide Appendix A Resolution, 1 3 1940.

('78', 211, 1, 2, 429389) What the vast Hindu masses and the others will say or do I do not know.
('78', 211, 1, 3, 429461) My mission is to work for the unity of all, for the sake of the equal good of all.
('78', 211, 1, 4, 429544) WHAT SHOULD BE DONES?
('78', 211, 2, 5, 429566) Q. In the last meeting 1 of the Working Committee the Committee have resolved that all Congress committees should either be transformed into satyagraha committees of the office bearers, who for any reason cannot sign the pledge, should resign and make room for others who have signed the pledge.
('78', 211, 2, 6, 429862) Now, if any Congressman has no faith in your technique but has accepted it only to carry out the Working Committees resolution and is spinning only because he wants to remain in office, is he entitled to become a satyagrahi and remain in office?
('78', 211, 3, 7, 430108) A. Surely the office bearers should resign.
('78', 211, 3, 8, 430152) The pledge taken merely to remain in office is of no value.

('78', 211, 4, 10, 430250) FOR NON PERPORMANCE
('78', 211, 5, 11, 430270) Q. If anyone signing the satyagraha pledge does not observe the rules laid down in it, what action will be taken against such a satyagrahi?
('78', 211, 6, 12, 430410) A. He is liable to be removed from the position he may hold.
('78', 211, 6, 13, 430471) IF A COMMITTEE REFUSES
('78', 211, 7, 14, 430494) Q. If a Congress committee refuses to transform itself into a satyagraha committee, what is the position of that committee?
('78', 211, 8, 15, 430618) A. That area will be unrepresented unless there are other Con gressmen to take the place of the defunct committee?
('78', 211, 8, 16, 430733) CAN THEY TAKE THE PLEDGE?

('78', 211, 13, 21, 431113) A. These persons cannot take the pledge.

('78', 212, 10, 14, 432061) 227. NON CO OPERATION
('78', 212, 11, 15, 432083) The following is from a godfearing political friend whom everybody knows: 3
('78', 212, 12, 16, 432159) I have been closely following your experiments in ahimsa and
('78', 212, 13, 17, 432220) satyagraha .
('78', 212, 13, 18, 432233) But I tell you these weapons of yours have been and are being
('78', 212, 14, 19, 432295) abused in the world .
('78', 212, 14, 20, 432317) Non co operation has become a curse in everyday life.
('78', 212, 15, 21, 432371) Its ill effects are seen in family circles, in associations, in business, in
('78', 212, 16, 22, 432448) factories and in Government offices.
('78', 212, 17, 23, 432485) Having learnt its use from you, selfish people use it in your name in order to gain their selfish ends, and bring misery upon thousand of people.
('78', 212, 17, 24, 432631) Therefore I beg of you not to employ this weapon in politics .
('78', 212, 18, 25, 432694) I request you not to embarrass the British in any way while they are engaged in this life and death struggle.
('78', 212, 18, 26, 432804) But I know, by itself the Congress will not have the patience to do so, though it may under your advice.
('78', 212, 19, 27, 432909) 1 Vide Notes, 16 2 1940.
('78', 212, 20, 28, 432934) 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('78', 213, 0, 1, 432971) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 213, 1, 2, 433013) If the Congressmen must embarrass the British, I feel they should go back to offices in the Provinces and should face the British Government with a dilemma at every step in the Provincial and the Central Assemblies.
('78', 213, 2, 3, 433229) Again we have to solve the Hindu Muslim problem.
('78', 213, 2, 4, 433278) For that we should
('78', 213, 3, 5, 433297) call a conference of all the communal leaders and party leaders.
('78', 213, 3, 6, 433362) If we make an
('78', 213, 4, 7, 433376) effort before hand, we might become united by the time the Government is
('78', 213, 5, 8, 433449) willing to call Constituent Assembly.
('78', 213, 5, 9, 433487) No time should be lost.
('78', 213, 5, 10, 433511) The demands
('78', 213, 6, 11, 433523) of the Mussalmans will mount up as time goes on.
('78', 213, 6, 12, 433572) I am certain God will
('78', 213, 7, 13, 433594) help us to attain unity if we try for it is right earnest and without delay.
('78', 213, 7, 14, 433671) The writer is one of the most earnest among us.
('78', 213, 7, 15, 433719) He has presented one side of the picture, but like all one sided pictures this also is misleading.
('78', 213, 7, 16, 433818) Every powerful thing is liable to misuse.
('78', 213, 7, 17, 433860) Opium and arsenic are most potent and useful drugs.
('78', 213, 7, 18, 433912) And they lend themselves to great abuse.
('78', 213, 7, 19, 433953) No one has for that reason suggested the stopping of their good use.
('78', 213, 7, 20, 434022) If no co operation has lent itself to abuse in some cases, in many cases its wise use has proved absolutely efficacious.
('78', 213, 7, 21, 434143) A thing has to be judged by its net effect.
('78', 213, 7, 22, 434187) The net effect of no violent no co operation has been of the greatest benefit to India.
('78', 213, 7, 23, 434275) It has brought about an awakening among the masses which would probably have taken generations otherwise.
('78', 213, 7, 24, 434381) It has prevented bloodshed and anarchy and on the whole improved the relations between the Britishers and ourselves.
('78', 213, 7, 25, 434498) There is a better mutual understanding because there is better mutual respect than ever before.
('78', 213, 7, 26, 434594) And yet our no co operation has been indifferently non violent.
('78', 213, 7, 27, 434658) I hold that no co operation is of universal use.
('78', 213, 7, 28, 434707) Well applied, its use in politics can wholly displace the use of barbarous weapons of mutual destruction.
('78', 213, 7, 29, 434813) The thing to do, therefore, is not to restrict its use but to extend it, care being taken that it is used in accordance with the known laws regulating its use.
('78', 213, 7, 30, 434973) Risk of misuse has undoubtedly to be run.
('78', 213, 7, 31, 435015) But with the increase in the knowledge of its right use, the risk can be minimized.
('78', 213, 7, 32, 435099) One safe thing about non co operation is that in the end its abuse recoils more upon the users than upon those against whom it is used.
('78', 213, 7, 33, 435235) Its abuse is the greatest in domestic relations because those against whom it is used are not strong enough to resist the abuse.
('78', 213, 7, 34, 435364) It becomes a case of misapplied affection.
('78', 213, 7, 35, 435407) Doting parents or wives are the greatest victims.
('78', 213, 7, 36, 435457) These will learn wisdom when they realize that
('78', 214, 0, 1, 435504) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 215
('78', 214, 1, 2, 435549) affection does not demand yielding to extortion in any form.
('78', 214, 1, 3, 435610) On the contrary true affection will resist it.
('78', 214, 1, 4, 435657) The writer suggests that usual parliamentary programme with obstruction.
('78', 214, 1, 5, 435730) It futility, when it is not backed by readiness for no co operation and civil disobedience, has been fully demonstrated.
('78', 214, 1, 6, 435851) So far as the British are concerned I have already said that I will do nothing to embarrass them.
('78', 214, 1, 7, 435949) I straining every nerve to avoid a conflict.
('78', 214, 1, 8, 435994) But they may make it inevitable.
('78', 214, 1, 9, 436027) Even so, I am praying for a mode of application which will be effective and still not embarrassing in the sense of violent outbreaks throughout the country.
('78', 214, 1, 10, 436184) Here I must say that, whilst it is true that active co operation on the part of Congressmen is not yet much in evidence, of passive co operation on their part there is no lack.
('78', 214, 1, 11, 436361) Violent, sporadic eruptions on the part of the people would have paralysed my effort to gather together forces of non violence in an effective manner.
('78', 214, 1, 12, 436512) As it is, the restraint which they have exercised fills me with hope for the future.
('78', 214, 1, 13, 436597) Hindu Muslim unity is a morsel by itself.
('78', 214, 1, 14, 436639) But my friend is on the wrong track when he suggests that unity should be hastened for fear of Muslims raising their demands.
('78', 214, 1, 15, 436765) Demands against whom?
('78', 214, 1, 16, 436787) India is as much theirs as anybody elses.
('78', 214, 1, 17, 436829) The way to unity lies through just demands once for all, not through ever increasing demands, whether just or unjust.
('78', 214, 1, 18, 436947) The demand for partition puts an end to all effort for unity for the time being.
('78', 214, 1, 19, 437028) I hold that communal understanding is not a pre requisite to the British doing justice on their part.
('78', 214, 1, 20, 437130) When they feel that they want to recognize Indias right of self determination, all the difficulties that they put forth as obstacles in their path will melt away like ice before the suns rays.
('78', 214, 1, 21, 437323) The right of self determination means the right of determination by every group and ultimately every individual.
('78', 214, 1, 22, 437436) The demand for a Constituent Assembly presumes that the determinations of the groups and individuals will coincide.
('78', 214, 1, 23, 437552) Should it happen otherwise and partition become the fashion, either we shall have partition or partitions rather than foreign rule, or we shall conti nue to wrangle among ourselves and submit to foreign rule, or else have a proper civil war.
('78', 214, 1, 24, 437794) Anyway the present suspense cannot conti nue.
('78', 214, 1, 25, 437840) It has to end one way or the other.
('78', 214, 1, 26, 437876) I am an optimist.
('78', 214, 1, 27, 437894) I have every hope that when we come to grips Hindus, Muslims and all others will throw in favour of India which all will claim as their own.
('78', 214, 1, 28, 438035) SEVAGRAM, May 13, 1940

('78', 226, 0, 1, 453103) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 227
('78', 226, 1, 2, 453148) 247. QUESTION BOX
('78', 226, 2, 3, 453166) SPINNING REGULARLY
('78', 226, 3, 4, 453185) Q. What do you mean by spinning regularly?
('78', 226, 3, 5, 453228) 1 If one spins for a couple of hours during a month or for half an hour once or twice a week, would he be deemed to have satisfied the condition about spinning regularly?
('78', 226, 3, 6, 453399) A. Regularly was put in the place of daily.
('78', 226, 3, 7, 453443) This was meant to provide for accidental or unavoidable omissions.
('78', 226, 3, 8, 453510) Therefore spin ning every week or at stated intervals will not meet the case.
('78', 226, 3, 9, 453588) A satyagrahi will be expected to spin daily except for valid reasons such as sickness, travelling or the like.
('78', 226, 3, 10, 453699) SATYAGRAHA CAMPS AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('78', 226, 4, 11, 453735) Q. Satyagraha camps are being organized for the training of volunteers all over the country.
('78', 226, 4, 12, 453828) But the principle with regard to the renunciation of untouchability in every shape and form is not being rigorously enforced.
('78', 226, 4, 13, 453954) Dont you agree that it ought to be made an absolute rule in the camps that no one who regards the touch of Harijans as polluting and does not freely mix with them should be permitted to attend them?
('78', 226, 4, 14, 454153) A. I have no hesitation whatsoever in saying that he who has the slightest untouchability in him is wholly unfit for enrolment in the Satyagraha Sena.
('78', 226, 4, 15, 454304) I regard untouchability as the root cause of our downfall and of Hindu Muslim discord.
('78', 226, 4, 16, 454391) Untouchability is the curse of Hinduism and therefore of India.
('78', 226, 4, 17, 454455) The taint is so pervasive that it haunts a man even after he has changed over to another faith.
('78', 226, 4, 18, 454551) PARTITION AND NON MUSLIMS
('78', 226, 5, 19, 454577) Q. You have said in Harijan that If the eight crores of Muslims desire partition, no power on earth can prevent it. 2 Does it not strike you that 25 crores of non Muslims too might have a say in the matter?
('78', 226, 5, 20, 454784) Does not your statement imply that you put a premium on the opinion of the Muslims while underrating that of Hindus?
('78', 226, 5, 21, 454901) A. I have only given my opinion.
('78', 226, 5, 22, 454934) If the majority of Hindus or Christians or Sikhs or even Parsis, small though their number is, stub bornly resist the express wish of the duly elected representatives of eight crores of Muslims, they will do so at the peril of a civil war.
('78', 226, 5, 23, 455174) This is not a question of majority of minority.
('78', 226, 5, 24, 455222) If we are to solve our problems non violently, there is no other way.
('78', 226, 5, 25, 455292) I say this not because
('78', 226, 6, 26, 455315) 1 Vide Appendix Satyagraha Pledge, before 1 6 1940.
('78', 226, 7, 27, 455367) 2 Vide Hindu Muslim Tangle , 29 4 1940
('78', 227, 0, 1, 455406) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 227, 1, 2, 455448) the eight crores happen to be Muslims.
('78', 227, 1, 3, 455487) I would say the same if the eight crores were any other community.
('78', 227, 1, 4, 455554) LEGAL PRACTICE AND SATYAGRAHA
('78', 227, 2, 5, 455584) Q. Knowing as you do how lying and deceit have become the stock in trade of the legal profession in this country, would you permit practising lawyers to enlist as active satyagrahis?
('78', 227, 2, 6, 455767) A. I am unable to subscribe to your sweeping proposition.
('78', 227, 2, 7, 455825) The fact that a lawyer wants to become a satyagrahi presupposes on his part a certain standard of purification.
('78', 227, 2, 8, 455937) No doubt there may be, to my knowledge there are, black sheep in the Congress.
('78', 227, 2, 9, 456016) This is inevitable in any big organization.
('78', 227, 2, 10, 456060) But it would be unbecoming of a satyagrahi to condemn a man because he belongs to a certain profession.
('78', 227, 2, 11, 456164) SATYAGRAHA AND OBSTRUCTIONISM
('78', 227, 3, 12, 456194) Q. Is the policy of obstructionism compatible with satyagraha?
('78', 227, 3, 13, 456257) Can a satyagrahi, who is supposed to stand for principles rather than party, adopt one attitude with regard to a measure when it is sponsored by his party, and another when the same measure is sponsored by the opposite party?
('78', 227, 3, 14, 456483) Would you approve of this policy in municipalities and district boards as is being done by some Congressmen at present?
('78', 227, 3, 15, 456603) A. I have always opposed obstruction as being anti satyagraha.
('78', 227, 3, 16, 456666) Congressmen, to be correct in their behaviour, should always give co operation to their opponents when the latter are in a majority and adopt any wise measure.
('78', 227, 3, 17, 456826) The object of Congressmen should never be attainment of power for powers sake.
('78', 227, 3, 18, 456905) Indeed such discriminatory co operation will enhance the prestige of the Congress and may even give it majority.
('78', 227, 3, 19, 457018) TRAINING HARIJANS AS COOKS
('78', 227, 4, 20, 457045) Q. Dont you think that, if the Congress started a plan for training Harijans as expert cooks for Hindu homes and made it a rule to man every ashram of a mess meant for Congress workers with Harijan cooks thus trained, it would prove a short cut to the removal of untouchability?
('78', 227, 5, 21, 457324) A. Our ambition should be to enable Harijan to rise to the highest rank.
('78', 227, 5, 22, 457397) But while that must be the ideal, it will be a good thing to train some Harijan to become accomplished cooks.
('78', 227, 5, 23, 457507) I have observed that the move we draw them into the domestic circle the quicker is the pace of the reform.
('78', 227, 5, 24, 457614) Harijans who become absorbed in out homes lose all sense of inferiority and become a living link between other Harijans and savarna Hindus.
('78', 227, 5, 25, 457754) SEVAGRAM, May 19, 1940 Harijan, 25 5 1940
('78', 228, 0, 1, 457796) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 229
('78', 228, 1, 2, 457841) 248. NOTES
('78', 228, 2, 3, 457852) NON RESISTANCE
('78', 228, 3, 4, 457867) I read the following in the daily Press:
('78', 228, 4, 5, 457908) A petition signed by a number of Muslims has been sent to the
('78', 228, 5, 6, 457970) Corporation authorities that, if their previous representations for the removal
('78', 228, 6, 7, 458050) of Gandhijis portrait from all Corporation schools for Muslims boys and
('78', 228, 7, 8, 458122) girls is not acceded to, the institutions will be boycotted.
('78', 228, 7, 9, 458183) They contend that
('78', 228, 8, 10, 458201) the display of the portrait is a form of hero worship, which is anti Islamic.
('78', 228, 8, 11, 458279) Assuming the truth of the statement I would strongly advise compliance with the Muslim demand.
('78', 228, 8, 12, 458374) Nothing is to be gained by the Congress party resisting the demand.
('78', 228, 8, 13, 458442) At the same time I would suggest to the leaders of the agitation that it is supported by wrong argument.
('78', 228, 8, 14, 458547) For they have surely their own heroes.
('78', 228, 8, 15, 458586) The proper and conclusive argument is that I am no longer their hero.
('78', 228, 8, 16, 458656) Heroes change with the times.
('78', 228, 8, 17, 458686) It is well for public bodies to accommodate themselves to such changes.
('78', 228, 8, 18, 458758) FIVE QUESTIONS
('78', 228, 9, 19, 458773) 1. Can satyagrahis (i.e., those who have signed the satyagraha pledge) offer
('78', 228, 10, 20, 458850) defence when they are arrested?
('78', 228, 11, 21, 458882) 2. May a satyagrahi make an effort to get better class treatment, i.e., A or
('78', 228, 13, 22, 458959) 3. Ought a satyagrahi in jail to acquiesce in the conditions imposed upon
('78', 228, 14, 23, 459033) him, or should be endeavour to secure that he regards more humane and satisfactory
('78', 228, 15, 24, 459116) treatment?
('78', 228, 16, 25, 459127) 4. What is the minimum time for which a satyagrahi ought to spin or what is
('78', 228, 17, 26, 459203) the minimum quantity of yarn he should produce?
('78', 228, 18, 27, 459251) 5. Can a man sign the satyagraha pledge immediately you declare civil
('78', 228, 19, 28, 459321) disobedience and court arrest, or is there any definite period for which he should have
('78', 228, 20, 29, 459409) remained a satyagrahi to be eligible to take part in the civil disobedience campaign?
('78', 228, 20, 30, 459495) Answers: 1. There is no objection to offering defence, and in certain cases it would be a duty to do so as, say, in the Ajmer case.
('78', 228, 20, 31, 459627) 2. In my opinion he should not make any attempt to alter the class, Personally I am against an classification.
('78', 229, 0, 1, 459738) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 229, 1, 2, 459780) 3. He is entitled to make every legitimate effort for change to humane conditions.
('78', 229, 1, 3, 459863) 4. I think one hour per day should be the minimum and 300 rounds per hour is a reasonable speed.
('78', 229, 1, 4, 459960) Men engaged in public work may spin less.
('78', 229, 1, 5, 460002) 5. A man who intentionally refrains from signing a pledge in order to avoid fulfilment of conditions is a cheat and unworthy of being a satyagrahi.
('78', 229, 1, 6, 460150) But I can conceive an honest man just signing the pledge and straightaway going to jail.
('78', 229, 1, 7, 460239) Even at the risk of losing prospective pledge takers and those who have taken the pledge.
('78', 229, 1, 8, 460329) I would say that there is no immediate prospect of my giving the call.
('78', 229, 1, 9, 460400) SEVAGRAM, May 20, 1940
('78', 229, 2, 10, 460423) Harijan, 25 5 1940
('78', 229, 3, 11, 460442) 249. OUR DUTY
('78', 229, 4, 12, 460456) In view of further ruthless aggression by Nazi Germany and the fact
('78', 229, 5, 13, 460524) that Britain is hard pressed and going through deep waters today, does not
('78', 229, 6, 14, 460599) non violence demand that we should say to her that, while we do not resile in
('78', 229, 7, 15, 460677) the very least from our position nor withdraw an iota of our demand so far as
('78', 229, 8, 16, 460755) her relationship with us and our future are concerned, we do not desire to
('78', 229, 9, 17, 460830) embarrass her in dire distress and will definitely, therefor, defer all thoughts
('78', 229, 10, 18, 460911) and all talk of a civil disobedience movement for the time being?
('78', 229, 10, 19, 460977) Do not our
('78', 229, 11, 20, 460988) minds rebel against the very idea of a domination such as Nazidom is
('78', 229, 12, 21, 461057) avowedly standing for today?
('78', 229, 12, 22, 461086) Is not the whole future of a humane civilization
('78', 229, 13, 23, 461135) at stake?
('78', 229, 13, 24, 461145) It is true that our independence from an alien rule is also a matter of
('78', 229, 14, 25, 461217) life and death to us.
('78', 229, 14, 26, 461239) But when Britain is up against an aggressor who is defini 
('78', 229, 15, 27, 461298) tely pursuing barbarous methods, should we not make a timely and humane
('78', 229, 16, 28, 461370) gesture which should in the end win the heart of our opponent?
('78', 229, 16, 29, 461433) Even if such a
('78', 229, 17, 30, 461448) gesture makes no impression on her and an honourable settlement is impos 
('78', 229, 18, 31, 461522) sible, will it still not be the higher and ennobling thing for us to offer non 
('78', 229, 19, 32, 461602) violent battle when she is not beset on all sides?
('78', 229, 19, 33, 461653) Will it not require greater
('78', 229, 20, 34, 461681) strength in us and therefore mean greater and more lasting benefit, and will it not
('78', 229, 21, 35, 461765) be a glorious example for a warring world?
('78', 229, 21, 36, 461808) Will it not also be a proof that non violence is pre eminently a weapon of the strong?
('78', 229, 21, 37, 461895) Perhaps this correctly represents the sentiment of several correspondents who have written to me since the Norwegian setback.
('78', 230, 0, 1, 462021) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 231
('78', 230, 1, 2, 462066) It is evidence of the nobility of the hearts of these correspondents.
('78', 230, 1, 3, 462136) But there is want of appreciation of the reality.
('78', 230, 1, 4, 462186) These letters ignore British nature.
('78', 230, 1, 5, 462223) British people stand in no need of sympathy from subject people.
('78', 230, 1, 6, 462288) For they can command all they want from them.
('78', 230, 1, 7, 462334) They are a brave and proud people.
('78', 230, 1, 8, 462369) They are not going to be demoralized by even half a dozen such setbacks.
('78', 230, 1, 9, 462442) They are well able to cope with any difficulty that may face them.
('78', 230, 1, 10, 462509) India has no say whatsoever in the manner in which she is to take her part in the war.
('78', 230, 1, 11, 462596) She was dragged into the war by the mere wish of the British Cabinet.
('78', 230, 1, 12, 462666) Her resources are being utilized at the will of the British Cabinet.
('78', 230, 1, 13, 462735) India is a dependency, and Britain will drain the dependency dry as she has done in the past.
('78', 230, 1, 14, 462829) What gesture has the Congress to make in these circumstances?
('78', 230, 1, 15, 462891) The greatest gesture in its power the Congress is already making.
('78', 230, 1, 16, 462957) It creates no trouble in the country.
('78', 230, 1, 17, 462995) It refrains in pursuance of its own policy.
('78', 230, 1, 18, 463039) I have said and I repeat that I shall do nothing wilfully to embarrass Britain.
('78', 230, 1, 19, 463119) It will be contrary to my conception of satyagraha.
('78', 230, 1, 20, 463171) Beyond this it is not in the power of the Congress to go.
('78', 230, 1, 21, 463229) Indeed it is the duty of the Congress to prosecute its demand for independence and to continue the preparations for civil disobe dience to the fullest extent it can.
('78', 230, 1, 22, 463395) The nature of the preparations should be appreciated: to promote khadi and village industries, com munal unity, removal of untouchability, prohibition, and to this end to enlist and train Congress members.
('78', 230, 1, 23, 463601) Is this preparation to be suspen ded?
('78', 230, 1, 24, 463639) I dare say that, if the Congress truly becomes non violent and in pursuance of the policy of non violence it successfully carries out the constructive work I have mentioned, it will be able to have indepen dence without doubt.
('78', 230, 1, 25, 463866) Then will be the time for India as an indepen dent nation to decide what aid she should give to Britain and how.
('78', 230, 1, 26, 463979) The Congress contribution to the cause of the Allies in so far as it may be good, and to the world peace, is its active pursuance of non violence and truth and the prosecution of its goal of complete independence without abatement and without delay.
('78', 230, 1, 27, 464229) Britain is really damaging her own cause by persistently refusing to examine the Congress position and recognize its justice and in raising false issues.
('78', 230, 1, 28, 464383) The Constituent Assembly of the kind proposed by me provides for every difficulty except one, if it is a difficulty.
('78', 230, 1, 29, 464500) It does not provide for British interference in the shaping of Indias destiny.
('78', 230, 1, 30, 464579) If that is put forth as a difficulty, the Congress
('78', 231, 0, 1, 464630) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 231, 1, 2, 464672) must wait till it is acknowledged that it is not only no difficulty but that self determination is Indias indisputable right.
('78', 231, 1, 3, 464798) In this connection let me refer to the letters I have received accusing me of unwillingness to declare civil disobedience under some pretext or other.
('78', 231, 1, 4, 464949) These friends must know that I am more concerned than they in the successful demonstration of the weapon of non violence.
('78', 231, 1, 5, 465071) I am not giving myself a minutes rest from the pursuit of the search.
('78', 231, 1, 6, 465141) I am ceaselessly praying for light.
('78', 231, 1, 7, 465177) But I cannot precipitate civil disobedience because of outside pressure, even as I will not refrain because of such pressure.
('78', 231, 1, 8, 465303) I know that this is the time of my greatest trial.
('78', 231, 1, 9, 465354) I have overwhelming evidence to show that there is much violence in the hearts of many Congressmen and that there is much selfishness.
('78', 231, 1, 10, 465489) If Congressmen were imbued with the true spirit of non violence, we would have had independence in 1921 and our history would have been written differently.
('78', 231, 1, 11, 465646) But I must not complain.
('78', 231, 1, 12, 465671) I must work with the tools I have.
('78', 231, 1, 13, 465706) Only let Congressmen know the cause of my seeming inaction.
('78', 231, 1, 14, 465766) SEVAGRAM, May 20, 1940 Harijan, 25 5 1940

('78', 243, 3, 10, 480175) 275. LETTER TO BALVANTSINHA
('78', 243, 4, 11, 480203) SEVAGRAM,, May 24, 1940
('78', 243, 5, 12, 480227) BALVANTSHINHA,
('78', 243, 6, 13, 480242) I have gone through your letter.
('78', 243, 6, 14, 480275) The thing is that Parnerkar says he cannot all by himself look after the three jobs; the milkroom, the cattle and the farming.
('78', 243, 6, 15, 480402) He is therefore agreeable to cattle and farming being transferred to you.
('78', 243, 6, 16, 480476) I like this arrangement and then you have to help Parnerkar quite a lot in his work.
('78', 243, 6, 17, 480561) Chimanlal and Munnalal, to the extent they understand the problem, also approve.
('78', 243, 6, 18, 480642) Parnerkar also accepts if not wholly.
('78', 243, 6, 19, 480680) The reason he advances is that he is short handed.
('78', 243, 6, 20, 480731) Under the circumstances, it becomes my duty to entrust cattle and farming to your care.
('78', 243, 6, 21, 480819) I do not like the idea of forming a committee.
('78', 243, 6, 22, 480866) You can take me to be the committee.
('78', 243, 6, 23, 480903) If I need anyones help I shall take it, otherwise I shall decide matters myself.
('78', 243, 6, 24, 480984) In effect this will mean that many things will be left to you.
('78', 243, 6, 25, 481047) As far as possible let the goshala be as it is.
('78', 243, 6, 26, 481095) If experience demands any change, it will be made.
('78', 243, 6, 27, 481146) As for servants only those will remain who are good.
('78', 243, 6, 28, 481199) We must grow our own vegetables.
('78', 243, 6, 29, 481232) We are already using our own cotton.
('78', 243, 6, 30, 481269) The fruit tree must be taken good care of.
('78', 243, 6, 31, 481312) This is my view.
('78', 243, 6, 32, 481329) But if for any reason your heart is not in this work, I shall not insist.
('78', 243, 6, 33, 481403) If you wish to go to Nathji 1 for some days, do go.
('78', 243, 6, 34, 481455) And if you wish to do some work on a larger scale, you should certainly do so.
('78', 243, 6, 35, 481534) If you take up this work you should do so with feeling of satisfaction and as a duty.
('78', 243, 7, 36, 481620) 1 Kedarnath Kulkarni
('78', 244, 0, 1, 481641) VOL,78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 245
('78', 244, 1, 2, 481686) You should not take it up on my account; because I have no knowledge of these things.
('78', 244, 1, 3, 481772) I want to entrust you with the work because you are here and I have confidence in you.

('78', 244, 5, 6, 481916) 276. STATEMENT TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS 1
('78', 244, 6, 7, 481957) WARDHA, May 24, 1940
('78', 244, 7, 8, 481978) While hourly butchery is going on in the West and peaceful homes are being destroyed, I have no heart to say anything publicly in regard to Mr. Amerys statement in answer to Mr. Wedgwood Benn in the House of Commons.
('78', 244, 8, 9, 482195) Suffice it to say that I would leave no stone unturned to bring about a peaceful and honourable settlement of the present deadlock.
('78', 244, 8, 10, 482327) The Hitavada, 25 5 1940
('78', 244, 9, 11, 482351) 1 This was also published in Harijan, 1 6 1940, under the title "Will Leave No Stone Unturned".
('78', 244, 9, 12, 482447) Gandhi was lying in his cottage with a wet piece of cloth over his head on account of the blazing heat when the Associated Press representative presented Amery's statement in the Commons to Gandhiji.
('78', 244, 9, 13, 482647) Gandhiji read the statement carefully and then appeared to think deeply for a few minutes.
('78', 244, 9, 14, 482738) he then took paper and pencil and himself wrote out the statement.
('78', 244, 9, 15, 482805) 2 On May 23, L. S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, had said in the Commons: The attainment by India of full and equal partnership in the British Common wealth is the goal of our policy.
('78', 244, 9, 16, 482996) We recognize, as my predecessor made clear in his speech on April 18, that it is for Indians themselves to play a vital part in devishing a form of constitution best adapted to India's conditions and India's outlook.
('78', 244, 9, 17, 483213) The promise already given that the present scheme of the Act of 1935 and the policy and plans on which it is based are to be open for re examination at the end of the war necessarily implies discussion and negotiation, and not dictation.
('78', 244, 9, 18, 483451) we have no desire to delay any of the steps that may pave the way towards an agreed settlement that will take account of the legitimate claims of all communities and interests.
('78', 244, 9, 19, 483628) on the contrary, we have been, and are only too anxious to make our contribution towards such a settlement.

('78', 248, 1, 2, 487636) 283. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR
('78', 248, 2, 3, 487666) SEVAGRAM, May 25, 1940
('78', 248, 3, 4, 487689) SUSHILA,
('78', 248, 4, 5, 487698) Your last sentence was unbecoming of you.
('78', 248, 4, 6, 487740) I do not want a relevant truth, I do not want a half truth, I want the whole truth think over its meaning.
('78', 248, 4, 7, 487847) So long as you are at Sevagram the question of what your duty and mine is does not arise at all.
('78', 248, 4, 8, 487944) You may well believe that you are here on my account and I may think that because you are here I should take service from you.
('78', 248, 4, 9, 488071) When there is an occasion to go out, I am faced with a dilemma, not you.
('78', 248, 4, 10, 488144) If, thinking otherwise, I act differently, then it is self deception.
('78', 248, 4, 11, 488214) That cannot happen in Sevagram because I am already taking service from you.
('78', 248, 4, 12, 488291) If this distinction is not clear to you, let both of us leave the matter to God.
('78', 248, 4, 13, 488372) When God reveals to us your or my mistake, you or I shall correct it.
('78', 248, 4, 14, 488442) I have told you that so long as the mists have not rolled away, you must stay.
('78', 248, 4, 15, 488521) If you do not feel certain about it, do as you like.
('78', 248, 4, 16, 488574) Do nothing under any pressure.
('78', 248, 4, 17, 488605) Do only what brings you self satisfaction.
('78', 248, 4, 18, 488648) Ultimately, only what you think to be your duty would be your duty.

('78', 249, 1, 2, 488884) 284. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR
('78', 249, 2, 3, 488914) SEVAGRAM, May 25, 1940
('78', 249, 3, 4, 488937) STUPID GIRL, You really are stupidity incarnate.
('78', 249, 3, 5, 488986) I do not understand your letter at all.
('78', 249, 3, 6, 489026) How have you become a sinner because I told you an untruth?
('78', 249, 3, 7, 489086) I want to keep you with me, but not by making you believe an untruth.
('78', 249, 3, 8, 489156) It was due to love that I resorted to the untruth.
('78', 249, 3, 9, 489207) There was attachment in that love.
('78', 249, 3, 10, 489242) How are you at fault in that?
('78', 249, 3, 11, 489272) If at all, it is I who should undertake a fast.
('78', 249, 3, 12, 489320) But I will not do so because my untruth was not so very sinful.
('78', 249, 3, 13, 489384) If you undertake a fast, you will cause me pain and add to the wrong which you are doing.
('78', 249, 3, 14, 489474) If you are keen to see your mistake, abide in peace.
('78', 249, 3, 15, 489527) So long as I am here, you will continue to serve.
('78', 249, 3, 16, 489577) Then you will see your mistake.
('78', 249, 3, 17, 489609) But if you cannot endure it, do go.
('78', 249, 3, 18, 489645) One day you will discover your mistake and laugh.
('78', 249, 3, 19, 489695) You have your reason for staying whether I believe in it or not.
('78', 249, 3, 20, 489760) You can stay out of the Ashram if I go out and do not take you along.
('78', 249, 3, 21, 489830) Why run away now?
('78', 249, 3, 22, 489848) Why are you not ashamed of running away?
('78', 249, 3, 23, 489889) What did I write to hurt you?
('78', 249, 3, 24, 489919) What should I write?
('78', 249, 3, 25, 489940) I am ashamed of your stupidity.
('78', 249, 3, 26, 489972) I should certainly fast to cure you of your stupidity.
('78', 249, 3, 27, 490027) This is not tragic.
('78', 249, 3, 28, 490047) It is comic.
('78', 249, 3, 29, 490060) Blessings from BAPU
('78', 249, 4, 30, 490080) From the Hindi original: Pyarelal Papers.
('78', 249, 4, 31, 490122) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
