('78', 430, 1, 2, 832858) 507. THE BEST FIELD FOR AHIMSA 1
('78', 430, 2, 3, 832891) Last week I wrote about three fields for the operation of ahimsa.
('78', 430, 2, 4, 832957) 2 I propose to invite attention today to the fourth and the best field for the operation of non violence.
('78', 430, 2, 5, 833063) This is the family field, in a wider sense than the ordinary.
('78', 430, 2, 6, 833125) Thus members of an institution should be regarded as a family.
('78', 430, 2, 7, 833188) Non violence as between the members of such families should be easy to practise.
('78', 430, 2, 8, 833269) If that fails, it means that we have not developed the capacity for pure non violence.
('78', 430, 2, 9, 833356) For the love we have to practise towards our relatives or colleagues in our family or institution, we have to practise towards our foes, dacoits, etc.
('78', 430, 2, 10, 833507) If we fail in one case, success in the other is a chimera.
('78', 430, 2, 11, 833566) We have generally assumed that, though it may not be possible to exercise non violence in the domestic field, it is possible to do so in the political field.
('78', 430, 2, 12, 833724) This has proved a pure delusion.
('78', 430, 2, 13, 833757) We have chosen to describe our methods adopted so far as non violence, and thus caricatured non violence itself.
('78', 430, 2, 14, 833870) If non violence it was, it was such poor stuff that it proved useless at the critical moment.
('78', 430, 2, 15, 833964) The alphabet of ahimsa is best learnt in the domestic school, and I can say from experience that, if we secure success there, we are sure to do so every where else.
('78', 430, 2, 16, 834129) For a non violent person the whole world is one family.
('78', 430, 2, 17, 834185) He will thus fear none, nor will others fear him.
('78', 430, 2, 18, 834235) It will be retorted that those who satisfy such a test of non violence will be few and far between.
('78', 430, 2, 19, 834335) It is quite likely, but that is no reply to my proposition.
('78', 430, 2, 20, 834395) Those who profess to believe in non violence should know the implications of that belief.
('78', 430, 2, 21, 834485) And if these scare them away, they are welcome to give up the belief.
('78', 430, 2, 22, 834555) Now that the Congress Working Committee has made the position clear, it is necessary that those who claim to believe in non violence should know what is expected to them.
('78', 430, 2, 23, 834726) If, as a result, the ranks of the non violent army thin down, it should not matter.
('78', 430, 2, 24, 834810) An army, however small, of truly non violent soldiers is likely some day to multiply itself.
('78', 430, 2, 25, 834903) An army of those who are not truly non violent is never likely to yield any use whether it increases or decreases.
('78', 430, 2, 26, 835018) Let no one understand from the foregoing that a non violent army is open only to those who strictly enforce in their lives all the
('78', 430, 3, 27, 835149) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijan bandhu, 20 7 1940. This translation is taken from Harijan.
('78', 430, 3, 28, 835265) 2 Vide  A Cry in the Wilderness?, 8 7 1940
('78', 431, 0, 1, 835308) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 431, 1, 2, 835350) implications of non violence.
('78', 431, 1, 3, 835380) It is open to all those who accept the implications and make an ever increasing endeavour to observe them.
('78', 431, 1, 4, 835487) There never will be an army of perfectly non violent people.
('78', 431, 1, 5, 835548) It will be formed of those who will honestly endeavour to observe non violence.
('78', 431, 1, 6, 835628) For the last fifty years I have striven to make my life increasingly non violent and to inspire my co workers in the same direction, and I think I have had a fair amount of success.
('78', 431, 1, 7, 835810) The growing darkness around, far from damping my zeal and dimming my faith, brightens them, and makes the implications of non violence more clearly visible to me.
('78', 431, 1, 8, 835973) SEVAGARAM, July 15, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940
('78', 431, 2, 9, 836017) 508. A WORTHY EDUCATIONAL EFFORT 1
('78', 431, 3, 10, 836052) The Birla family have been running an institution called the Birla College at Pilani in Jaipur State.
('78', 431, 3, 11, 836154) I have been often asked to visit it, but in spite of my keen desire to do so I have never been able to find time for it.
('78', 431, 3, 12, 836275) Thakkar Bapa visited the institution and gave me a glowing account and pressed me to visit it.
('78', 431, 3, 13, 836370) Seth Ghanshyamdas Birla has now issued a booklet to acquaint the public about the origin and growth of the institution.
('78', 431, 3, 14, 836490) The object is to invite criticism and to present the public with its novel features, may be for adoption.
('78', 431, 3, 15, 836596) The writer has lavished on the booklet all his art of writing, aided by fine printing, beautiful illustrations alluringly arranged, making the whole thing very attractive.
('78', 431, 3, 16, 836768) For two months Mahadev waited for a suitable opportunity to place it before me, and imagining that I should have some spare time on our journey to Simla he ventured to give it to me on the train.
('78', 431, 3, 17, 836964) The moment I took it up to read, it gripped me.
('78', 431, 3, 18, 837012) It is a quarto size booklet of 47 pages, and I could not give it up until I had read it from cover to cove.
('78', 431, 3, 19, 837120) I would ask all interested in education to write for it to the Secretary of the Birla College, Pilani.
('78', 431, 3, 20, 837223) A brief history of the enterprise may be given here.
('78', 431, 3, 21, 837276) The institution has grown out of a small school called Birlas Pathshala opened 40 years ago in an insignificant little building.
('78', 431, 3, 22, 837405) Now it is an institution with an intermediate College, splendid buildings for school,
('78', 431, 4, 23, 837491) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 20 7 1940. This translation is taken from Harijan.
('78', 432, 0, 1, 837606) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 433
('78', 432, 1, 2, 837651) college and hostels, and vast playgrounds.
('78', 432, 1, 3, 837694) It has 33 staff quarters, and 5 hostels accommodating 295 students (including 27 Harijan).
('78', 432, 1, 4, 837785) There are 18 playgrounds, a library with 3,608 Hindi and 6,772 English books.
('78', 432, 1, 5, 837863) There is high school with 791 boys, a college with 165 boys, and a girls school with 157 girls.
('78', 432, 1, 6, 837959) The Birla Educational Trust runs besides 128 village schools with 4,636 boys and 200 girls.
('78', 432, 1, 7, 838051) Physical instruction and games are compulsory, and so is music.
('78', 432, 1, 8, 838115) There is an agricultural farm with a dairy on modern lines.
('78', 432, 1, 9, 838175) Among the crafts and vocations taught are spinning and weaving, carpentry, tailoring, dye ing, printing, book binding, weaving, carpet making, shoe making and leather work.
('78', 432, 1, 10, 838348) The agricultural farm and dairy have numerous cows, sheep and goats.
('78', 432, 1, 11, 838417) The basic education scheme is also being given a trial.
('78', 432, 1, 12, 838473) Hardly anything has escaped the attention of those in charge prayer, intellectual and industrial training, balanced diet, health exa mination and health preservation.
('78', 432, 1, 13, 838640) An endeavour is made to develop individual contact between the students and teachers on a family basis.
('78', 432, 1, 14, 838744) The whole institution has grown out of Seth Shivnarayanji Birlas desire to provide for the education of his two grandsons Rame shwardas and Ghanshyamdas.
('78', 432, 1, 15, 838898) He did not like the provision to be con fined to the needs of his grandsons, and so he established a school in 1900 with a village teacher on Rs. 5 a month for all the children of the village.
('78', 432, 1, 16, 839091) This was called the Birla Pathshala the seed out of which has grown the vast tree that the institution now has become.
('78', 432, 1, 17, 839210) It combines family interests with philanthropy which has now become a distinctive trait of the Birla brothers.
('78', 432, 1, 18, 839321) But Ghanshyamdas, of all the brothers, made a special interest of education, health and kindred topics, and the growth of the institution at Pilani is mainly due to his persever ance, resourcefulness and interest in education.
('78', 432, 1, 19, 839548) Sir Maurice Gwyer and other distinguished people have visited the institution and spoken in high terms about it.
('78', 432, 1, 20, 839661) Ghanshyamdasjis ambition is to make a Degree College of the Intermediate College, and he has been trying to do so for some years.
('78', 432, 1, 21, 839791) But things move slowly in Princes India, and so his ambition still remains unfulfilled, it is hoped that the Jaipur State will lose no time in encouraging this worthy enterprise and accord permission to turn it into a full fledged college.
('78', 432, 1, 22, 840031) In my opin ion there are few institutions in India run with such care and attention.
('78', 432, 1, 23, 840116) If we assume the necessity for modern colleges, the Birla col lege has succeeded in combining several features which are scarcely to be seen elsewhere in India.
('78', 432, 1, 24, 840277) SEVAGRAM, July 15, 1940 Harijan, 28 7 1940
('78', 433, 0, 1, 840320) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 433, 1, 2, 840362) 509. ONE MORE FACTION?
('78', 433, 2, 3, 840385) Q. Does not the resolution of the Working Committee mean that it adds one more to the existing factions?
('78', 433, 3, 4, 840490) A. I do not think there is room for such a fear or doubt.
('78', 433, 3, 5, 840548) Let us see what happens in the A. I. C. C. If it is found that a large majority of the members are believers in strict non violence I have no doubt that Sardar Vallabhbhai and other will be extremely delighted.
('78', 433, 3, 6, 840759) It was no pleasure to them to arrive at the decision they did, and they acted in their representative capacity.
('78', 433, 3, 7, 840871) They acted in the belief that there were very few Congressmen with a genuine faith in non violence, and they had sufficient reasons for their belief.
('78', 433, 3, 8, 841021) Had it been a question of their individual belief, I am sure they would have unhesitatingly voted for non violence.
('78', 433, 3, 9, 841137) Assuming, therefore, that the truly non violent are in a minority, it will be their duty to leave the Congress and thus serve the Congress all the better.
('78', 433, 3, 10, 841292) Their continuance in the Congress would lead to friction, for the majority would, in carrying out their policy, have to adopt many resolutions which the followers of out and out non violence could not accept.
('78', 433, 3, 11, 841501) That would lead to clashes which should be anything but non violence.The out and out non violent, therefore, will gladly retire and devote themselves exclusively to cons tructive work.
('78', 433, 3, 12, 841686) They will also co operate with the Congress wherever they can do so without a clash, and yet they will not think of being in any committee.
('78', 433, 3, 13, 841826) I am firmly of opinion that, if we can bring into being an army of truly non violent persons, the Working Committees decision will be found to be a blessing in disguise.
('78', 433, 3, 14, 841996) If every province has its band of truly non violent soldiers, they will not only add to the glory of the Congress but contribute effectively to bringing the Con gress nearer to non violence than ever before.
('78', 433, 4, 15, 842204) SEVAGRAM, JULY 15, 1940
('78', 433, 5, 16, 842228) Harijan, 28 7 1940

('78', 435, 11, 14, 844164) 513. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR

('78', 435, 14, 17, 844235) I have received your letter of complaint.

('78', 435, 14, 19, 844302) In fact I wrote you a letter before I reached Mathura.
('78', 435, 14, 20, 844357) But Pyarelal did not like it.
('78', 435, 14, 21, 844387) His argument convinced me, so I cancelled the letter and asked him to tear it up.

('78', 435, 14, 23, 844501) After that I wrote three letters between Itarsi and Wardha.

('78', 437, 0, 1, 845917) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 437, 1, 2, 845959) APPENDICES
('78', 437, 2, 3, 845970) APPENDIX I
('78', 437, 3, 4, 845981) A RESOLUTION 1
('78', 437, 5, 5, 845996) March 1, 1940
('78', 437, 6, 6, 846010) This Congress, having considered the grave and critical situation resulting from the War in Europe and British policy in regard to it, approves of and endorses the resolutions passed and the action taken on the War situation by the A.I.C.C. and the Working Committee.
('78', 437, 6, 7, 846278) The Congress considers the declaration by the British Government of India as a belligerent country, without any reference to the people of India, and the exploitation of Indias resources in this war, as an affront to them which no self respecting and freedom loving people can accept or tolerate.
('78', 437, 6, 8, 846575) The recent pronouncements made on behalf of the British Government in regard to India demonstrate that Great Britain is carrying on the war fundamentally for imperialist ends and for the preservation and strengthening of her Empire, which is based on the exploitation of the people of India, as well as of other Asiatic and African countries.
('78', 437, 6, 9, 846918) Under these circumstances, it is clear that the Congress cannot in any way, directly or indirectly, be party to the war, which means continuance and perpetuation of this exploitation.
('78', 437, 6, 10, 847102) The Congress, therefore, strongly disapproves of Indian troops being made to fight for Great Britain and of the drain from India of men and material for the purpose of the war.
('78', 437, 6, 11, 847279) Neither the recruiting nor the money raised in India can be considered to be voluntary contributions from India.
('78', 437, 6, 12, 847392) Congressmen, and those under the Congress influence, cannot help in the prosecution of the war with men, money or material.
('78', 437, 6, 13, 847516) The Congress hereby declares again that nothing short of complete independence can be accepted by the people of India.
('78', 437, 6, 14, 847635) Indian freedom cannot exist within the orbit of imperialism and Dominion Status or any other status within the imperial structure is wholly inapplicable to India, is not in keeping with the dignity of a great nation, and would bind India in many ways to British policies and economic structure.
('78', 437, 6, 15, 847930) The people of India alone can properly shape their own constitution and determine their relations to the other countries of the world, through a Constituent
('78', 437, 7, 16, 848087) 1 Gandhijis draft was approved by the Working Committee and recommended for adoption at the Congress Session at Ramgarh.
('78', 437, 7, 17, 848208) It appeared in Harijan under the title India and the War.
('78', 437, 7, 18, 848266) Vide Statement to the Press, 2 3 1940; When?, 5 3 1940For Englishmen, 11 3 1940; Question Box, 12 3 1940; Speech at Subjects Committee, 18 3 1940 and Jayaprakashs Picture, 14 4 1940.
('78', 438, 0, 1, 848449) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 439
('78', 438, 1, 2, 848494) Assembly elected on the basis of adult suffrage.
('78', 438, 1, 3, 848543) The Congress is further of opinion that while it will always be ready, as it ever has been, to make every effort to secure communal harmony, no permanent solution is possible except through a Constituent Assembly, where the rights of all recognized minorities will be fully protected by agreement, as far as possible, between the elected representatives of various majority and minority groups, or by arbitration if agreement is not reached on any point.
('78', 438, 1, 4, 848998) Any alternative will lack finality.
('78', 438, 1, 5, 849034) Indias constitution must be based on independence, democracy and national unity, and the Congress repudiates attempts to divide India or to split up her nationhood.
('78', 438, 1, 6, 849199) The Congress has always aimed at a constitution where the fullest freedom and opportunities of development are guaranteed to the group and the individual, and social injustice yields place to a juster social order.
('78', 438, 1, 7, 849414) The Congress cannot admit the right of the Rulers of Indian States, or of foreign vested interests, to come in the way of Indian freedom.
('78', 438, 1, 8, 849552) Sovereignty in India must rest with the people, whether in the States or the Provinces, and all other interests must be subordinated to their vital interests.
('78', 438, 1, 9, 849711) The Congress holds that the difficulty raised in regard to the States is of British creation, and it will not be satisfactorily solved unless the declaration of the freedom of India from foreign rule is unequivocally made.
('78', 438, 1, 10, 849934) Foreign interests, if they are not in conflict with the interests of the Indian people, will be protected.
('78', 438, 1, 11, 850041) The Congress withdrew the Ministries from the Provinces where the Congress had a majority in order to dissociate India from the war and to enforce the Congress determination to free India from foreign domination.
('78', 438, 1, 12, 850254) This preliminary step must naturally be followed by civil disobedience, to which the Congress will unhesitatingly resort as soon as the Congress organization is considered fit enough for the purpose, or in case circumstances so shape themselves as to precipitate a crisis.
('78', 438, 1, 13, 850527) The Congress desires to draw the attention of Congressmen to Gandhijis declaration that he can only undertake the responsibility of declaring civil disobedience when he is satisfied that they are strictly observing discipline and are carrying out the constructive programme prescribed in the Independence Pledge.
('78', 438, 1, 14, 850840) The Congress seeks to represent and serve all classes and communities without distinction of race or religion, and the struggle for Indian independence is for the freedom of the whole nation.
('78', 438, 1, 15, 851032) Hence the Congress cherishes the hope that all classes and communities will take part in it.
('78', 438, 1, 16, 851125) The purpose of civil disobedience is to evoke the spirit of sacrifice in the whole nation.
('78', 438, 2, 17, 851216) The Congress hereby authorizes the All India Congress Committee, and in the event of this being necessary, the Working Committee, to take all steps to implement the foregoing resolution as the Committee concerned may deem necessary.
('78', 438, 3, 18, 851449) Harijan, 9 3 1940
('78', 439, 0, 1, 851467) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 439, 1, 2, 851509) APPENDIX II
('78', 439, 2, 3, 851521) JAYAPRAKASH NARAYANS STATEMENT 1
('78', 439, 3, 4, 851554) I have been charged with trying to impede the production of munitions and other supplies essential to the efficient prosecution of the war, and with trying to influence the conduct and attitude of the public in a manner prejudicial to the defence of British India and the efficient prosecution of the war.
('78', 439, 3, 5, 851860) I plead guilty to these charges.
('78', 439, 4, 6, 851893) These charges, however, do not constitute a guilt for me but a duty which I discharge regardless of the consequence.
('78', 439, 4, 7, 852010) That they also constitute an offence under certain laws of the foreign Government, established by force in this country, does not concern me.
('78', 439, 4, 8, 852152) The object of these laws is diametrically opposed to the object of nationalist India of which I am but an humble representative.
('78', 439, 4, 9, 852281) That we should come in conflict is only natural.
('78', 439, 4, 10, 852330) My country is not a party to this war in any manner, for it regards both German Nazism and British Imperialism as evils and enemies.
('78', 439, 4, 11, 852463) It finds that both the sides in this war are driven by selfish ends of conquest and domination, exploitation and oppression.
('78', 439, 4, 12, 852588) Great Britain is fighting not to destroy Nazism, which it has nurtured, but to curb a rival whose might can no longer be allowed to grow unchallenged.
('78', 439, 4, 13, 852739) It is fighting to maintain its dominant place in the world and to preserve its imperial power and glory.
('78', 439, 4, 14, 852844) As far as India is concerned, Great Britain is fighting to perpetuate the Indian Empire.
('78', 439, 5, 15, 852933) Plainly, India can have no truck with such a war.
('78', 439, 5, 16, 852983) No Indian can permit the resources of his country to be utilized to buttress up imperialism, and to be converted through the processes of the war into the chains of his countrys slavery.
('78', 439, 5, 17, 853170) The Congress, the only representative voice of nationalist India, has already pointed out this sacred duty to the people of this country.
('78', 439, 5, 18, 853308) I, as an humble servant of the Congress, have only tried to fulfil this duty.
('78', 439, 6, 19, 853386) The British Government on the other hand, in utter disregard for Indian opinion, has declared India a belligerent power and is utilizing Indian men, money and materials for a war to which we have pledged our uncompromising opposition.
('78', 439, 6, 20, 853621) This is in the nature of an aggression against India, no less serious in the circumstances than German aggression against Poland.
('78', 439, 6, 21, 853751) India cannot but resist this aggression.
('78', 439, 6, 22, 853792) It therefore becomes the patriotic duty of every Indian to oppose the attempt of the British Government to use the countrys resources for its imperialist ends.
('78', 439, 6, 23, 853952) Thus the charge framed against me of trying to impede the efficient prosecution of the war is only the fulfilment of a patriotic duty.
('78', 439, 6, 24, 854087) That the British Government should consider what is a duty for patriotic India to be an offence, only proves further
('78', 439, 7, 25, 854204) 1 Vide A Brave Statement, 26 3 1940.
('78', 440, 0, 1, 854241) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 441
('78', 440, 1, 2, 854286) its imperialist character.
('78', 440, 2, 3, 854313) Regarding the speech for which I am being prosecuted, I cannot say how far it succeeded in achieving its ends.
('78', 440, 2, 4, 854424) But nothing would please me more than to learn that it did have some success in impeding the effective prosecution of the war.
('78', 440, 2, 5, 854551) I shall deem the heaviest punishment well earned if I am found to have succeeded in this.
('78', 440, 3, 6, 854641) As for the charge of endangering the defence of British India, I think the irony of it cannot be lost upon us.
('78', 440, 3, 7, 854752) A slave has no obligation to defend his slavery.
('78', 440, 3, 8, 854801) His only obligation is to destroy his bondage.
('78', 440, 3, 9, 854848) I hope we shall know how to defend ourselves when we have achieved our freedom.
('78', 440, 4, 10, 854928) I consider it fortunate that I have been prosecuted for a Jamshedpur speech.
('78', 440, 4, 11, 855005) This important industrial centre, which I consider the most important in the country, is peculiarly backward politically and from the point of view of the labour movement.
('78', 440, 4, 12, 855177) I shall derive some satisfaction in prison, where I expect inevitably to find myself, from the thought that my arrest and incarceration for a speech delivered there has attracted to that city the notice of the political and labour leaders of my country.
('78', 440, 4, 13, 855431) It seems scandalous to me that the countrys most vital resources should be so wasted in a war to which we are so firmly opposed.
('78', 440, 4, 14, 855560) And it seems no less scandalous to me that while labour throughout the country should be reacting vigorously to the conditions created by the war, Jamshedpur labour should carry on as if nothing extraordinary has happened.
('78', 440, 4, 15, 855783) May, at least, the demand for a war bonus gain some momentum from this prosecution.
('78', 440, 5, 16, 855867) Before concluding I should like to add that, lest as an Englishman you should misunderstand me, I should make it clear that in impeding the prosecution of the war I have no desire to help Germany or to see Germany victorious.
('78', 440, 5, 17, 856093) I desire the victory neither of Imperialism nor of Nazism.
('78', 440, 5, 18, 856152) Yet, as a Congressman and a socialist I have nothing but goodwill for the British and German people.
('78', 440, 5, 19, 856253) If Indias opposition to Britains imperialist war ensures a Nazi victory, it is for the British people to decide whether they would have Nazi hegemony or victory with real democracy at home and in India.
('78', 440, 5, 20, 856456) If the people of Great Britain remove their present rule and renounce imperialism with its capitalist rulers, not only India but the freedom loving people of the whole world exert themselves to see the defeat of Nazism and the victory of freedom and democracy.
('78', 440, 5, 21, 856717) In the present circumstances, however, India has no alternative but to fight and end British imperialism.
('78', 440, 5, 22, 856823) Only in that manner can it contribute to the peace and progress of the world.
('78', 440, 6, 23, 856901) I am conscious, Sir, that I have made your task easier by this statement.
('78', 440, 6, 24, 856975) I do not regret it.
('78', 440, 7, 25, 856995) In the end I thank you for your courtesy and consideration during the trial.
('78', 440, 8, 26, 857072) Harijan, 30 3 1940

('78', 441, 1, 2, 857133) APPENDIX III
('78', 441, 2, 3, 857146) RESOLUTION PASSED BY ALL INDIA MUSLIM LEAGUE 1
('78', 441, 3, 4, 857193) March 23, 1940
('78', 441, 4, 5, 857208) 1. While approving and endorsing the action taken by the Council and the Working Committee of the All India Muslim League, as indicated in their resolutions dated the 27th of August, 17th and 18th of September and 22nd of October 1939 and 3rd of February 1940 on the constitutional issue, this session of the All India Muslim League emphatically reiterates that the scheme of Federation embodied in the Government of India Act, 1935, is totally unsuited to and unworkable in the peculiar conditions of this country and is altogether unacceptable to Muslim India.
('78', 441, 5, 6, 857771) 2. It further records its emphatic view that while the declaration dated the 18th of October 1939, made by the Viceroy on behalf of His Majestys Government, is reassuring in so far as it declares that the policy and plan on which the Government of India Act, 1935, is based will be reconsidered in consultation with the various parties, interests and communities in India, Muslim India will not be satisfied unless the whole constitutional plan is reconsidered de novo and that no revised plan would
('78', 441, 6, 7, 858271) be acceptable to the Muslims unless it is framed with their approval and consent.
('78', 441, 6, 8, 858353) 3. Resolved that it is the considered view of this session of the All India Muslim League that no constitutional plan would be workable in this country or acceptable to the Muslims unless it is designed on the following basic principle, viz., that geographically contiguous units are demarcated into regions which should be so constituted with such territorial readjustments as may be necessary that the areas in which the Muslims are numerically in a majority, as in the north western and eastern zones of India, should be grouped to constitute independent states in which the constituent units shall be autonomous and sovereign.
('78', 441, 7, 9, 858984) That adequate, effective and mandatory safeguards should be specifically provided in the constitution for minorities in the units and in the regions for the protection of their religious, cultural, economic, political, administrative and other rights and interests in consultation with them and in other parts of India where the Mussalmans are in a minority, adequate, effective and mandatory safeguards shall be specifically provided in the constitution for them and other minorities for the protection of their religious, cultural, economic, political, administrative and other rights and interests in consultation with them.
('78', 441, 8, 10, 859612) This session further authorizes the Working Committee to frame a scheme of
('78', 441, 9, 11, 859687) 1 Vide A Baffling Situation, 1 4 1940 and Letter to Abdul Kalam Azad, 4 4 1940.
('78', 442, 0, 1, 859767) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 443
('78', 442, 1, 2, 859812) constitution in accordance with these basic principles providing for the assumption finally by the respective regions of all powers such as defence, external affairs, communications, customs and such other matters as may be necessary.
('78', 442, 2, 3, 860047) The Indian Annual Register, January June 1940, Vol. I, pp.
('78', 442, 3, 4, 860106) APPENDIX IV
('78', 442, 4, 5, 860118) LETTER FROM LORD LINLITHGOW 1
('78', 442, 5, 6, 860148) THE VICEROYS HOUSE,
('78', 442, 6, 7, 860168) NEW DELHI,
('78', 442, 7, 8, 860179) April 9, 1940
('78', 442, 8, 9, 860193) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('78', 442, 9, 10, 860210) Many thanks for your letter of 4th April and for your kindness in sending me the extract enclosed in it from a letter from Maulana A. K. Azad.
('78', 442, 10, 11, 860353) 2. It is obvious that the extract in question reveals some misunderstanding.
('78', 442, 10, 12, 860430) When we met on 4th November you asked me specifically, as you have indicated in your letter, whether the Dominion Status which His Majestys Government had in view for India was the Dominion Status of the Statute of Westminster variety.
('78', 442, 10, 13, 860666) I explained the position, and I took the steps at once to ask the Secretary of State to arrange in the House of Lords (as he did on 7th November 1939) to place the position beyond any question.
('78', 442, 10, 14, 860860) When we met on 5th February I again made the offer of His Majestys Government clear and stated the limits within which I could conduct negotiation.
('78', 442, 10, 15, 861008) You equally made your position clear, and I have no complaint whatever that you failed to do so.
('78', 442, 10, 16, 861105) That, in the light of my speech at Orient Club and of your first reaction to it, I was disappointed that the gulf between us should at our meeting on 5th February have proved to be so wide, you know as well as I do.
('78', 442, 10, 17, 861321) But there is no question of misunderstanding.
('78', 442, 11, 18, 861367) 3. As for His Majestys Government, I have never failed to keep them fully informed of what had passed between us, and I am sure there is no misapprehension in their minds.
('78', 442, 11, 19, 861539) I only wish that as the result of our various conversations I had found myself in a position to report that the hopes, indeed the confident hopes, I had at various times entertained and which, in accordance with my duty, I had not concealed from them, of a friendly settlement had been realized.
('78', 442, 12, 20, 861835) 4. I am sorry too that I should all unwittingly have involved you in, in your own words, this domestic dispute with your son.
('78', 442, 12, 21, 861961) For his friendly interest in the promotion of a settlement I am indeed grateful.
('78', 442, 12, 22, 862042) But you put the matter correctly when you say, as you say in your letter, that the gap revealed between the offer I was
('78', 442, 13, 23, 862162) 1 Vide Letter to Lord Linlithgow, 4 4 1940 and 12 4 1940.
('78', 443, 0, 1, 862220) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 443, 1, 2, 862262) empowered to make on behalf of His Majestys Government and the full demand which you put forward to me was clearly shown, as we both recognized, to be too great to be handled at that moment by prolonging conversations; and disappointed as I frankly was myself that that should have been the case, I think we were both right in feeling that the straightforward and courageous course in the circumstances that had disclosed themselves was to conclude those conversations as we did rather than to protract them.
('78', 443, 2, 3, 862771) Yours sincerely,
('78', 443, 3, 4, 862788) LINLITHGOW

('78', 443, 5, 8, 862890) APPENDIX V
('78', 443, 6, 9, 862901) EXTRACTS FROM LIAQUAT ALI KHANS STATEMENT 1
('78', 443, 7, 10, 862945) NEW DELHI,
('78', 443, 8, 11, 862956) April 4, 1940
('78', 443, 9, 12, 862970) Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan, Hon.
('78', 443, 9, 13, 863003) Secretary, All India Muslim League, in a statement to the Press .
('78', 443, 9, 14, 863069) refers to the article by Gandhiji in the Harijan under the caption, My Reply to Quaid e Azam and says :
('78', 443, 10, 15, 863173) Of course a politician who has a dual role, like Mr. Gandhi who is not even a four anna member of the Congress and yet its virtual dictator, has always a greater advantage over ordinary mortals.
('78', 443, 10, 16, 863368) He tells us for the first time that Whatever talks I had with Quaid e Azam or any other have been on behalf of the Congress.
('78', 443, 11, 17, 863493) Yet in his letter dated the 8th March 1938 addressed to Mr. Jinnah, Mr. Gandhi stated as follows :
('78', 443, 12, 18, 863592) You expect me to be able to speak on behalf of the Congress and other Hindus throughout the country.
('78', 443, 12, 19, 863693) I am afraid I cannot fulfil the test.
('78', 443, 12, 20, 863731) I cannot represent either the Congress or the Hindus in the sense you mean; but I would exert to the utmost all the moral influence I could have with them in order to secure an honourable settlement. It is indeed very difficult to know exactly when Mr. Gandhi speaks for himself and when he speaks for the Congress.
('78', 443, 12, 21, 864047) Mr. Gandhi goes on to say in his article that the Congress is not a Hindu organization and in support of this he puts forward the following argument.
('78', 443, 12, 22, 864197) Can a Hindu organization have a Muslim divine as President.
('78', 443, 12, 23, 864257) ? He would have the world believe that because Maulana Abul Kalam Azad has been elected President of the Congress therefore the true Hindu character of that body
('78', 443, 13, 24, 864419) 1 Vide My Position, 9 4 1940.
('78', 444, 0, 1, 864449) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 445
('78', 444, 1, 2, 864494) has changed.
('78', 444, 1, 3, 864507) May I point out to Mr. Gandhi that one swallow does not make a summer and the world cannot be so easily fooled.
('78', 444, 1, 4, 864619) Maulana Azads election as President of the Congress at this time is a tactical device to mislead the ignorant and the credulous.
('78', 444, 1, 5, 864748) And what does the Muslim divine himself think about his election ?
('78', 444, 1, 6, 864815) At the time of Maulana Azads election to the Presidentship of the Congress he is reported to have said that he regarded his election as a vote of confidence in the leadership of Mr. Gandhi and the countrys approval of his programme. Mr. Gandhi goes on to say that I still maintain that there is no swaraj without Hindu Muslim unity.
('78', 444, 1, 7, 865148) I can never be a party to the coercion of Muslims or any other minority.
('78', 444, 1, 8, 865221) The Constituent Assembly as conceived by me is not intended to coerce anybody.
('78', 444, 1, 9, 865300) Its sole sanction will be an agreed solution of communal question.
('78', 444, 1, 10, 865367) If there is no agreement the Constituent Assembly will be automatically dissolved. Further he goes on to say that If the vast majority of Indian Muslims feel that they are not one nation with their Hindu and other brethren who will be able to resist them ? There are a few pertinent questions which arise out of the above statement of Mr. Gandhi.
('78', 444, 1, 11, 865714) Mr. Gandhi has been saying for the last 20 years that there is no swaraj without Hindu Muslim unity and yet the Hindus and Muslims have never been so far apart from each other as they are today owing to the policy that has been followed by the Congress under the fostering care of Mr. Gandhi having for its sole objective the revival of Hinduism and the imposition of Hindu culture on all and sundry.
('78', 444, 1, 12, 866115) Mr. Gandhis description of the Constituent Assembly as conceived by him needs a great deal of clarification and explanation.
('78', 444, 1, 13, 866240) One would like to know if the Congress conception of the Constituent Assembly is the same as his own, as the resolution of the Congress is couched in different language to what Mr. Gandhi states in his article.
('78', 444, 1, 14, 866451) Mr. Gandhi now says that if there is no agreement the Constituent Assembly will be automatically dissolved; but not very long ago he had laid down that in the event of disagreement the matter will be referred to the highest and most impartial tribunal that the world can conceive of.
('78', 444, 1, 15, 866735) Mr. Gandhis statement that if the vast majority of Indian Muslims feel that they are not one nation with their Hindu and other brethren who will be able to resist them ? is rather interesting.
('78', 444, 2, 16, 866928) Is he prepared, that if the majority of Mussalmans declare in favour of the proposals of the Muslim League as laid down in the resolution passed at the Lahore session he and the Congress will give their whole hearted support to them ?
('78', 444, 3, 17, 867163) If so, let him and the Congress declare it unequivocally and in the plainest
('78', 444, 4, 18, 867240) language to that effect.
('78', 444, 4, 19, 867265) If the object of the Constituent Assembly is only to ascertain
('78', 444, 5, 20, 867328) whether the Mussalmans are in favour of the resolution of the Muslim League or not
('78', 444, 6, 21, 867411) then why go to all the trouble of dragging the whole country into a turmoil, as Mr.
('78', 444, 7, 22, 867495) Gandhi threatens to do by resorting to civil disobedience, to secure a Constituent
('78', 444, 8, 23, 867578) Assembly from the British Government ?
('78', 445, 0, 1, 867617) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 445, 1, 2, 867659) We have no doubt in our mind.
('78', 445, 1, 3, 867689) that the resolution passed at the Lahore session has the solid support of an overwhelming majority of Mussalmans.
('78', 445, 1, 4, 867803) Nevertheless let Mr. Gandhi and the Congress and the British Government declare unequivocally that if the majority of the Mussalmans express themselves in favour of the Lahore resolution they would agree to the demand contained in it and give effect to it, and the Muslim League, I have no doubt about it, will be prepared to satisfy any reasonable test; and in order to do that a Constituent Assembly is not necessary.
('78', 445, 2, 5, 868223) May I now most earnestly request Mr. Gandhi to lay down the test which would satisfy him in the first instance and describe the procedure categorically by means of which the Mussalmans could prove to the hilt that the Lahore resolution is the voice of Muslim India from one end of the country to the other ?
('78', 445, 3, 6, 868531) But if Mr. Gandhi wants that we should pull the chestnuts out of the fire for him and the Congress and save their faces by setting up some sort of Constituent Assembly then he is greatly mistaken.

('78', 445, 7, 10, 868791) TO THE SATYAGRAHA/CONGRESS COMMITTEE
('78', 445, 9, 11, 868828) I desire to enroll myself as an active satyagrahi.
('78', 445, 10, 12, 868879) I solemnly declare that,
('78', 445, 11, 13, 868904) (I) So long as I remain an active satyagrahi I shall remain non violent in word and deed and shall earnestly endeavour to be non violent in intent, since I believe that as India is circumstanced today, non violence alone can help and result in the attainment of purna swaraj and consolidation of unity among all the races and communities of India whether Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Parsi, Christian or Jew.
('78', 445, 12, 14, 869305) (2) I believe and shall endeavour always to promote such unity.
('78', 445, 13, 15, 869369) (3) I believe in the justice and necessity of removing the evil of untouchability and shall on all possible occasions seek personal contact with, and endeavour to render service to the submerged classes.
('78', 445, 14, 16, 869573) (4) I believe in swadeshi as essential for Indias economic, political and moral salvation and shall use hand spun and hand woven khaddar to the exclusion of every other cloth.
('78', 445, 14, 17, 869749) I shall so far as possible use the produce of hand and village industries.
('78', 445, 14, 18, 869824) (5) I shall spin regularly.
('78', 445, 15, 19, 869852) (6) I shall carry out the instructions of my superior officers and all rules and regulations not inconsistent with the spirit of this pledge prescribed by any superior

('78', 446, 1, 2, 870097) Congress organization or the Working Committee or any other agency established by the Congress.
('78', 446, 1, 3, 870193) (7) I am prepared to suffer imprisonment or even death for the sake of the cause and my country without resentment.
('78', 446, 1, 4, 870309) (8) In the event of my imprisonment I shall not claim from the Congress any support for myself, my family and dependants.

('78', 446, 7, 9, 870557) APPENDIX VII
('78', 446, 8, 10, 870570) DEENABANDHU MEMORIAL 1
('78', 446, 9, 11, 870593) Innumerable people all over the world, who have been plunged into sorrow by
('78', 446, 10, 12, 870669) the recent death of Charles Freer Andrews, must have been feeling, in their grief, that
('78', 446, 11, 13, 870757) it behoves his friends to carry on the work of service and reconciliation in which he
('78', 446, 12, 14, 870843) laboured so greatly.
('78', 446, 12, 15, 870864) We would not willingly let die the memory of his life; we seek a
('78', 446, 13, 16, 870929) way to perpetuate, in permanent and visible from, the spirit of that life.
('78', 446, 13, 17, 871004) Andrewss
('78', 446, 14, 18, 871013) permanent Indian home, the place with which for over a quarter of a century he
('78', 446, 15, 19, 871092) affectionately identified himself, was Santiniketan in the Birbhum District of Bengal.
('78', 446, 16, 20, 871179) This Ashram was originally founded by the late Maharshi Debendranath Tagore and
('78', 446, 17, 21, 871259) supported by the ancestral funds.
('78', 446, 17, 22, 871293) Under the leadership of his son, the Poet
('78', 446, 18, 23, 871335) Rabindranath Tagore, the educational institutions at Santiniketan, with the centre of
('78', 446, 19, 24, 871421) rural reconstruction close by at Sriniketan, have far outgrown the first conception,
('78', 446, 20, 25, 871506) and become a world famous centre of international culture.
('78', 446, 20, 26, 871565) To the welfare of these
('78', 446, 21, 27, 871589) institutions, with their vision of universal brotherhood and their service of
('78', 446, 22, 28, 871667) international understanding and peace, Andrews, the Poets closest friend, gave his
('78', 446, 23, 29, 871750) whole hearted devotion.
('78', 446, 23, 30, 871774) No private resources could be adequate for the support of such
('78', 446, 24, 31, 871837) a centre of study and research, and many of the financial and other contributions
('78', 446, 25, 32, 871919) which have been made to it from East and West alike have been owed to Andrewss
('78', 446, 26, 33, 871998) perseverance, hard work, and faith in its future.
('78', 446, 26, 34, 872048) No more fitting place can be
('78', 446, 27, 35, 872077) conceived for a memorial to him, nor one which he himself would have loved better,
('78', 446, 28, 36, 872160) as we who came into the closest contact with him know.
('78', 446, 29, 37, 872215) 1 Vide Notes, 10 6 1940. and Andrews Memorial, 27 8 1940.
('78', 447, 0, 1, 872273) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 447, 1, 2, 872315) It is true that no memorial in stone and mortar can fully perpetuate Andrewss
('78', 447, 2, 3, 872393) memory.
('78', 447, 2, 4, 872401) That can best be done by promoting true and lasting peace between India and
('78', 447, 3, 5, 872477) Great Britian as independent nations and, through their joint effort, universal peace.
('78', 447, 4, 6, 872564) But this work of reconciliation must find concrete form in some centre from which
('78', 447, 5, 7, 872646) his influence can radiate.
('78', 447, 5, 8, 872673) There could be no better memorial to him than the place
('78', 447, 6, 9, 872729) where he found his spiritual home and greatest human inspiration should be so
('78', 447, 7, 10, 872807) endowed as to enable it to fulfil his high hopes for it unhampered by the constant
('78', 447, 8, 11, 872890) financial anxiety with which it is now burdened.
('78', 447, 8, 12, 872939) In his name and that of the Poet
('78', 447, 9, 13, 872972) whose vision he so entirely shared, we appeal for this endowment to be generously
('78', 447, 11, 14, 873054) There are two projected developments of the work of Santiniketan and
('78', 447, 12, 15, 873123) Sriniketan which Charles Andrews himself specially longed to see.
('78', 447, 12, 16, 873189) The generous
('78', 447, 13, 17, 873202) response of the public to our appeal for a memorial fund will enable them both to be
('78', 447, 14, 18, 873287) carried out in addition to ensuring the permanence of the present established work.
('78', 447, 15, 19, 873371) They are as follows:
('78', 447, 16, 20, 873392) Andrews was most appropriately called Deenabandhu, the friend of the poor,
('78', 447, 17, 21, 873467) and the poor of the Birbhum district knew his friendship.
('78', 447, 17, 22, 873525) The rural centre at
('78', 447, 18, 23, 873545) Sriniketan has a good doctor and dispensary but no hospital or operating theatre.
('78', 447, 19, 24, 873627) propose to build a small but properly equipped hospital to serve the villages round us,
('78', 447, 20, 25, 873715) and to dig each year Deenabandhu wells in the neediest areas.
('78', 447, 20, 26, 873777) The Birbhum district is
('78', 447, 21, 27, 873801) not served by the large rivers of Bengal, and lack of adequate water supply is the main
('78', 447, 22, 28, 873889) cause of its grinding poverty.
('78', 447, 23, 29, 873920) It was true insight which caused an Indian friend to interpret the initials C. F. A. as meaning Christs Faithful Apostle.
('78', 447, 23, 30, 874042) Christ was the centre of his life.
('78', 447, 23, 31, 874077) Devotion to Him was his outstanding characteristic and the source of his inspiration and strength.
('78', 447, 23, 32, 874176) During the last months at Santiniketan he often expressed the hope that in this place, where the civilizations of the world can share with each other the bases of their strength, there might be established a Hall of Christian culture which could do for Indias thought through contact with the Western world, what the Cheena Bhawan is expected to do for our relationship with China.
('78', 447, 23, 33, 874558) The central purpose of the Hall would be the study of the teaching and character of Christ and its application to the solution of international problems.
('78', 447, 23, 34, 874712) It would seek to attract scholars and students, especially of the East, to the task of interpreting in their own modes of thought the spirit and mind of Christ.
('78', 447, 23, 35, 874873) We envisage a modest building, sufficiently endowed to enable us to offer such scholars and students a home at a minimum cost, with simple living accommodation, meeting hall, and the library whose nucleus Charles Andrews had already begun to assemble.
('78', 447, 23, 36, 875125) He himself made Santiniketan his headquarters during a life of practical Christian service which, reached our from here to the ends of the
('78', 448, 0, 1, 875264) VOL.78 : 23 FEBRUARY, 1940 15 JULY, 1940 449
('78', 448, 1, 2, 875309) We hope that such a Hall would enable others consecrated to the same kind of service to enjoy the same kind of home.
('78', 448, 2, 3, 875426) The full carrying out of this programme will require a fund of at least Rs.
('78', 448, 3, 4, 875502) 5,00,000 (40,000).
('78', 448, 3, 5, 875521) We ask Andrewss friends and admirers all over the world to
('78', 448, 4, 6, 875580) give liberal support to a scheme which will make possible, in his name, the
('78', 448, 5, 7, 875656) preservation and enrichment of this work nearest to his own heart.
('78', 448, 6, 8, 875723) Santiniketan and Sriniketan are in the charge of Dr. Rabindranath Tagore,
('78', 448, 7, 9, 875797) Founder President, Sir Nilratan Sarkar, Shri Hirendranath Datta, Shri L. K elehirst, Dr.
('78', 448, 8, 10, 875886) D. M. Bose, Treasurer, and Shri Rathindranath Tagore, General Secretary, as trustees.
('78', 448, 9, 11, 875972) The trust deed is registered.
('78', 448, 9, 12, 876002) Its corpus today is valued at Rs. 1,700,000. Its annual
('78', 448, 10, 13, 876058) expenditure is about Rs. 330,000.

('78', 448, 20, 23, 876244) APPENDIX VIII
('78', 448, 21, 24, 876258) RESOLUTION PASSED AT CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING AT DELHI 1
('78', 448, 22, 25, 876325) POLITICAL SITUATION
('78', 448, 23, 26, 876345) July 7, 1940
('78', 448, 24, 27, 876358) The Working Committee have noted the serious happenings which have
('78', 448, 25, 28, 876425) called forth fresh appeals to bring about a solution of the deadlock in the Indian
('78', 448, 26, 29, 876508) political situation; and in view of the desirability of clarifying the Congress position
('78', 448, 27, 30, 876597) they have earnestly examined the whole situation once again in the light of the latest
('78', 448, 28, 31, 876684) development in world affairs.
('78', 448, 29, 32, 876714) 1 Vide.
('78', 448, 29, 33, 876722) The Delhi Resolution, 8 7 1940 and Letter to Abdul Kalam Azad, 19 8 1940.
('78', 449, 0, 1, 876796) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('78', 449, 1, 2, 876838) The Working Committee are more than ever convinced that the acknow 
('78', 449, 2, 3, 876906) ledgment by Great Britain of the complete independence of India, is the only solu 
('78', 449, 3, 4, 876989) tion of the problems facing both India and Britain and are, therefore, of opinion that
('78', 449, 4, 5, 877076) such an unequivocal declaration should be immediately made and that as an immediate
('78', 449, 5, 6, 877160) step in giving effect to it, a provisional National Government should be constituted
('78', 449, 6, 7, 877245) at the Centre, which, though formed as a transitory measure, should be such as to
('78', 449, 7, 8, 877327) command the confidence of all the elected elements in the Central Legislature and
('78', 449, 8, 9, 877409) secure the closest co operation of the Responsible Government in the provinces.
('78', 449, 9, 10, 877489) The Working Committee are of opinion that unless the aforesaid declaration
('78', 449, 10, 11, 877564) is made, and a National Government accordingly formed at the Centre without delay,
('78', 449, 11, 12, 877647) all efforts at organizing the material and moral resources of the country for Defence
('78', 449, 12, 13, 877733) cannot in any sense be voluntary or as from a free country, and will therefore be
('78', 449, 13, 14, 877815) ineffective.
('78', 449, 13, 15, 877828) The Working Committee declare that if these measures are adopted, it will
('78', 449, 14, 16, 877902) enable the Congress to throw in its full weight in the efforts for the effective
('78', 449, 15, 17, 877983) organization of the Defence of the Country.
('78', 449, 16, 18, 878027) The Indian Annual Register, 1940, Vol. II, pp.
